revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-18 23:43:07.000000000', 'message': "Implement metadata options for snapshots

Initial BP was to enable update of metadata for snapshots,
as it turns out however snapshots don't currently have metadata at
all let alone update.

This patch implements metadata for snapshots as well as
the ability to update/delete that metadata.

Depends on Cinder side of changes: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/22253/

Partially implements blueprint: update-snap-metadata

Change-Id: I862e12837c1fb6bdd47908bfdd0e6044da560745
"}, {'created': '2013-02-21 03:56:32.000000000', 'message': 'Implement metadata options for snapshots

This patch implements metadata for snapshots as well as
the ability to update/delete that metadata.

Change-Id: I862e12837c1fb6bdd47908bfdd0e6044da560745
'}]
commit_message:
Implement metadata options for snapshots

This patch implements metadata for snapshots as well as
the ability to update/delete that metadata.

Change-Id: I862e12837c1fb6bdd47908bfdd0e6044da560745

commit_message:
package: consolidate get_packages logic

Refactor get_package logic.
With this refactoring, code like
"if is_ubuntu; then install_package xxx elif is_fedora..."
can be simplified later.

Change-Id: I489bfd4cc12cc6b0b8201837f2bfb78c6881c82c
Signed-off-by: Isaku Yamahata <yamahata@valinux.co.jp>

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-20 17:34:10.000000000', 'message': 'Allow acl with a valid token.

- When a user as a valid token it would go to authorize but the acl
  check was after the reseller_check and due fail. Check this before
  reseller_check and add a test for it.
- Fixes bug 1020722.

Change-Id: Iaff9f35f5ee690e9b729c36d05fb9adf3368dc79
'}]
commit_message:
Allow acl with a valid token.

- When a user as a valid token it would go to authorize but the acl
  check was after the reseller_check and due fail. Check this before
  reseller_check and add a test for it.
- Fixes bug 1020722.

Change-Id: Iaff9f35f5ee690e9b729c36d05fb9adf3368dc79

messages:
[{'account_id': 447, 'date': '2013-02-28 04:26:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (3 inline comments)

ok, thanks for the replies. 

I think the main limitation of doing it per pool would be that you couldn't have multiple VIPs that use the same IP, which seems important to several people.

Ok, ping me when you think there's something to test, even if it can only be used in limited ways.  I'll get a full test setup ready."}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2013-02-28 04:26:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (12 inline comments)

initial comments.  

only other thing to think about is exactly what a namespace should correspond to.  current design seems to map it to a pool.  But does that mean we can re-use a VIP IP address across multiple pools?  I think the original design tied a namespace more to tenant + subnet.  Still don't fully have my head wrapped around that part."}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2013-02-28 04:26:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (12 inline comments)

Thanks for the feedback.  Yeah this design is a 1:1 of pool and namespaces. I started out in the subnet direction, but ports could be on more than one subnet.  I'm wondering if the proper identifier is using the network_id.  Tying it to pools is also a bit of short cut since the implementation is easier.  I think we'd need to test how many namespaces is too many.  I'll a note to rework it for networks."}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2013-02-28 04:26:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2013-02-28 04:26:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I think I agree with both comments from enikanorov.  I definitely think we need another layer in naming, and i tend to think its better to have the files in fewer locations.'}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2013-02-28 04:26:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2013-02-28 04:26:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Work In Progress'}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2013-02-28 04:26:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (9 inline comments)

enikanorov, danwent:  Thank you for the reviews.  I was trying to avoid intermingling of vendor code and framework code in the same directory, but agree this does leave files in many locations.  The agent as written delegates much of the real work to the driver.  For now I'll move everything into plugins/services/loadbalancer.  We can revisit this in Havana since we'll need a pattern for vendors to introduce their solutions into the tree."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-28 04:26:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Doesn't seem to work

implements blueprint lbaas-namespace-agent

This a reference implemention of the Quantum load balancing service
using HAProxy.  The implemention is designed for vendors, developers,
and deployers to become familiar with the API and service workflow.

This change also adds some constraint checks for data integrity.

commit_message:
LBaaS Agent Reference Implementation

implements blueprint lbaas-namespace-agent

This a reference implemention of the Quantum load balancing service
using HAProxy.  The implemention is designed for vendors, developers,
and deployers to become familiar with the API and service workflow.

This change also adds some constraint checks for data integrity.

Change-Id: I10a67da11840477ccf063b98149f4f77248802a1

commit_message:
Added "/" check when list containers.

If there is a "/" in container name, print usage.

Fixs bug 1121897.

Change-Id: I633b5b7ff3a8dbc249ddd3c65439dd46c7d93b4a

commit_message:
Ensure downgrading baremetal-db from 004 drops instance_name

Table.drop_column(Column) does not seem to work with sqlite
while Table.drop_column('name_of_column') does.

Fix bug 1133235

Change-Id: Iaed4dffd4d1411665925d62a5a3e3798e353dbbc

commit_message:
Put heat data files in /var/lib/heat-cfntools

The /var/lib/heat-cfntools directory should be owned by the
heat-cfntools package for whichever distro it is included.

This avoids the problem of heat writing to directories owned
by cloud-init.

For the moment, the part handler will continue to write to
/var/lib/cloud/data to be removed at a later date.

Change-Id: I70b714c70ed146d4f6807850d6e7264c6a4624cd
Fixes: Bug #1105806

commit_message:
Improve logging for volume operations via manager

A large percentage of the logging information was
being done using debug.  This change moves some
of the logging information to be info level and
also tries to add some consistency in terms of
the general create/delete operations.

This includes moving logging for the basic operations
into the manager and omitting the repetive messages from
the drivers.

Fixes bug: 1133131

Change-Id: I792efde67f30d637431ad2fa45714e50bf9c705d

commit_message:
BM Migration 004: Actually drop column

SQLAlchemy-migrate appears to support passing in a Column or a
column-name string into `drop_column`. In practice though, only the
column-name form actually works.

Change-Id: I1bcc28511d652df44f7168fb84c8be7dacd60cfd

commit_message:
Actually run baremetal migration tests.

The baremetal migration tests weren't being run because the test lookup
code was looking for a tests of form 'check_#' instead of 'check_###'.

Change-Id: I8f162d6493dd09b2d0cff36c40ae9acc5df1269c

In real life, it happens that old VM run with flavors that have been
deleted. This wasn't handled properly.

This fixes bug #1131751

Change-Id: I11f32946394f0245f1696f29ff625b53a1a1cdb8
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>
"}]
commit_message:
compute: fix unknown flavor handling

In real life, it happens that old VM run with flavors that have been
deleted. This wasn't handled properly.

This fixes bug #1131751

Change-Id: I11f32946394f0245f1696f29ff625b53a1a1cdb8
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

commit_message:
nfs: raise exception for snapshots and volumes

create_snapshot create_volume_from_snapshot and
delete_snapshot is not available for the nfs driver.
So inform the user that is not available.

Fixes LP: #1097266

Change-Id: Ic5fb8c3018e0860fc8bce785bc15008868619937
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Remove E712 warning

When I run ./run_tests.sh it complains about these two lines. This patch
changes the == to is in order to remove the warnings.

E712 comparison to True should be 'if cond is True:' or 'if cond:'
	agents_db.Agent.admin_state_up == True)
E712 comparison to True should be 'if cond is True:' or 'if cond:'
	agents_db.Agent.admin_state_up == True)

Change-Id: I7693055cf4fd05be554e11e2e390b24a60d5fab0

[{'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-02-26 01:27:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I started to write a test for this, but it turned out to be fairly tricky. The issue is that snake-walk tests only runs for SQLite and not MySQL or Postgres which are the two databases that enforce FK constraints and would trip this error.

Some work will need to be done (eventually) to ensure that snake-walk tests run against the 'real' DBs so we can better flex FK constraints."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-26 02:05:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 4992, 'date': '2013-02-26 20:05:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Good work on spotting dependency and fixing order of operations. Would it not be wise to preserve the try-catch-block to log any exceptions that could arise?'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-02-26 23:28:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Would it not be wise to preserve the try-catch-block to log any exceptions that could arise?

I think in this case it's simpler and safer to just let the original exception bubble up and emit a useful stack-trace, at which point the logging statement becomes superflous.

If the exception handler was more specific and was guarding against a *specific* known-issue, and if the logging statement did more to clarify the situation, then I think a logging statement could be useful.

But here we have a generic exception handler with a generic logging message, so I don't think it has any particular value (other than making the code a bit more complex than it needs to be).

Side note:

Both of these exception handlers did something *bad*, in addition, so I felt it was a good idea to ax them.

In the upgrade, it called drop_all on both tables even though it's possible that `instance_action_events` hadn't been created yet.

In the downgrade, the exception handler was swallowing all exceptions."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2013-02-26 23:34:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

While not any worse than before and not specific to this migration, if an exception occurs, it could leave this migration partially applied. But probably so does every other migration right now.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-02-26 23:50:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Johannes: That's correct, I think very few, if any of our migrations are truly atomic.

IMHO, that should be a higher-level concern than the migration script.

If the migration engine, or a layer between script and engine, wants to implement transactional semantics, e.g. doing the work of keeping an undo-stack so it can rollback, that would be great.

But I think it would be a mistake for each script to try to work around this in a variety of ad hoc and buggy ways. (I know you weren't suggesting that, just mentioning for purposes of discussion :-)"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2013-02-27 00:14:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Yeah, it's out-of-scope for this patch at least. If only commands that alter tables were allowed in transactions..."}, {'account_id': 4992, 'date': '2013-02-27 00:19:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-02-27 13:31:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Thanks for fixing this up, especially the ordering.  The try/except blocks were carried over from other migrations, but don't add much value as you point out, and could be harmful."}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2013-02-27 17:30:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2013-02-27 21:11:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-26 01:23:37.000000000', 'message': 'Migration 148: Fix drop table dependency order

The downgrade of 148 was broken because instance_actions_events has a FK
dependency on instance_actions but was attempted to be deleted first,
which caused the sqlalchemy to complain.

The fix is to reorder the table deletes in the downgrade.

Additional cleanups:

* Remove unecessary exception handling which masked errors

Change-Id: Iaac77ba0e81071f6bb39e5cc3b599a4138eb3cd2
'}]
commit_message:
Migration 148: Fix drop table dependency order

The downgrade of 148 was broken because instance_actions_events has a FK
dependency on instance_actions but was attempted to be deleted first,
which caused the sqlalchemy to complain.

The fix is to reorder the table deletes in the downgrade.

Additional cleanups:

* Remove unecessary exception handling which masked errors

Change-Id: Iaac77ba0e81071f6bb39e5cc3b599a4138eb3cd2

Is there a way to fix this in a later migration? I'm concerned about people that managed to get past 147 already, and now their content is out of whack."}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2013-02-26 17:15:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Nice fix.'}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2013-02-26 18:02:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I agree with Sean. If there are users out there who have already run this migration aren't they going to be hurt? Especially since this migration went in late last year.

I think perhaps we should fix this migration (as here), but add a separate migration intended to catch the people who have already run this as well."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-02-26 19:27:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Is there a way to fix this in a later migration? I'm concerned about people that managed to get past 147 already, and now their content is out of whack.

This patch is intended to fix the problem of upgrade and downgrades not working properly for the purposes of testing.

Fixing bad data created as a result of running the broken 147 migration is a separate (but related) issue, IMHO.

Since fixing 147 doesn't harm people who have already run the migration (it doesn't magically fix data for them either as you point out), I don't think this should be that controversial."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-02-26 19:28:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> I think perhaps we should fix this migration (as here), but add a separate migration intended to catch the people who have already run this as well.

I'm confused by the -1.

As you state, 'we should fix this migration'. That's what this patch does.

I agree that it might be nice to fix the bad data generated by 147 for people who have already run it, but, IMHO, that is a separate problem and requires a separate patch."}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2013-02-27 17:35:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

There seems to be a lot of inconsistency in the standards to which we're holding migration patches. When this was all one set of migrations, it was too many in one place. I'm confused by the proposal to add an additional migration now. The reason to have a follow up migration is valid, but I agree with Rick that it should exist in a separate patch, and probably as a bug."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2013-02-27 23:23:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Let's get this fix in now so other people don't run into the bug"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-27 23:23:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

commit_message:
Migration 147: Prevent duplicate aggregate_hosts

If an aggregate_host record is already present, then the `upgrade`
shouldn't attempt to add it again.

Change-Id: Ib7ab10fa7c166ccaa3df6a96eb08c7ebcd0af38c

Verify Ubuntu Cloud Images using SHA256SUMS

by one of the CA's trusted by the build host.

@enikanorov

Re #1: The port is used to validate and reserve the requested address.  The port does not have an owner, so it can be used by the agent implementation however it needs including plugging into a namespace, attaching to a service VM, attaching to a service router, etc.

Re #2: This will be a known limitation for Grizzly. In Havana, we can add code to make it possible to run multiple services on the same valid ip address with different protocol ports.  If you notice the port_id is a read-only api attribute, to facilitate the sharing down the road.'}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2013-02-27 23:49:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-27 23:49:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

please add database migration script since the schema has changed'}, {'account_id': 6072, 'date': '2013-02-27 23:49:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Mark, there's few major concerns about this approach:

1. general concern on the creating quantum port for a VIP:
First object that user creates and that causes creation of device (or spawning haproxy process on the host) is pool creation.
In that case port is created by the driver: either directly (haproxy-on-host, routed insertion) or indirectly (launching VM)

VIP creation works with already established device.

2. You create quantum port per VIP, while VIPs could have same IP but different tcp ports. That doesn't seem correct."}, {'account_id': 6072, 'date': '2013-02-27 23:49:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

After discussion with folks we decided that patch is ok since limitation that it brings is not very important in the context of temporary solution (haproxy-on-host) that we make.

We're basing our code on this patch."}, {'account_id': 6447, 'date': '2013-02-27 23:49:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-27 23:49:45.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-27 23:49:45.000000000', 'message': 'create a Quantum port to reserve VIP address

fixes bug 1129672

The API previously allowed a VIP to be created without verifying that
the tenant had access to the subnet and that the address was valid and
available.  This change modifies VIP creation behavior to create a
Quantum port with the requested address.  If an address is not provided, an
address is allocated using the normal allocation process for the subnet.

This change also renames the port attribute to protocol_port to remove the
ambiguity about which type of port it represents.

Additional tests were added to validate the change in behavior.

Change-Id: Ib19ef653887da568364b4faa0d2c0fac30970b5f

commit_message:
create a Quantum port to reserve VIP address

fixes bug 1129672

The API previously allowed a VIP to be created without verifying that
the tenant had access to the subnet and that the address was valid and
available.  This change modifies VIP creation behavior to create a
Quantum port with the requested address.  If an address is not provided, an
address is allocated using the normal allocation process for the subnet.

This change also renames the port attribute to protocol_port to remove the
ambiguity about which type of port it represents.

Additional tests were added to validate the change in behavior.

Change-Id: Ib19ef653887da568364b4faa0d2c0fac30970b5f

commit_message:
NVP plugin support for dhcp network scheduling

blueprint quantum-scheduler

Note: since NVP already support scale-out + high availability for L3
this only implements scheduling for dhcp.

Also, we do not expose the API extension, just use the internal
auto-scheduling.

Change-Id: Ifd29439fd463972ae085e5d28ed1893f94f2a2d8

subject: NetApp: Fix race condition in 7-mode iSCSI driver with DFM.
messages:

[{'created': '2013-02-27 12:03:51.000000000', 'message': 'NetApp: Fix race condition in 7-mode iSCSI driver with DFM.

A race condition was discovered in the driver while creating
or deleting multiple volumes in a very short interval of time
(can be reproduced by making successive API calls to Cinder).
This fix decorates the methods responsible for race condition
with a synchronized() decorator. The problem was with the
management software: DFM, and in principle, there should not
be two processes trying to modify the DFM dataset object at
the same time. This patch prevents from such a possibility.

Fixes bug 1091480

Change-Id: I11cfc8868171acec356f4140aba52b8078d109df
'}]
commit_message:
NetApp: Fix race condition in 7-mode iSCSI driver with DFM.

A race condition was discovered in the driver while creating
or deleting multiple volumes in a very short interval of time
(can be reproduced by making successive API calls to Cinder).
This fix decorates the methods responsible for race condition
with a synchronized() decorator. The problem was with the
management software: DFM, and in principle, there should not
be two processes trying to modify the DFM dataset object at
the same time. This patch prevents from such a possibility.

Fixes bug 1091480

Change-Id: I11cfc8868171acec356f4140aba52b8078d109df

commit_message:
add the version requirement for testtools

when I run tempest, it display:
 'module' object has no attribute 'WithAttributes'.
But I have install testtools. when I upgrade testtools, the problem
is resovled. So I think we should require the version of testtools
in pip-requires.

Fixes bug 1133177

Change-Id: Ib30fa31f1a412981263bf93bc37c5f1d3918cf1f

commit_message:
Fixes the provisioning on selected volumes for NetApp 7 mode.

The current direct driver for 7 mode provisions openstack
volume on all NetApp 7 mode volumes mixing openstack volumes
with all non openstack volumes. This fix allows volume selection
by the user to keep openstack volumes separate from non opnestack
block storage entities.

bug 1132834

Change-Id: I77b78ce304e72482724b6ff7c52795c60992243e

commit_message:
Force log entries to be one line

Different versions of syslog-ng and probably other syslog services
handle multi line log messages differently and sometimes quite
poorly. This patch collapses multi line log messages into single
lines before sending them on to syslog.

It's just a copy of what was already in Python's logging.Formatter
but altered to replace the newlines with #012. I used #012 since
that's a convention we've already used elsewhere in Swift.

Change-Id: I8d0509b7cf48e45c2cf6480b51c67eec5bc94fe2

commit_message:
Port safe parsing with minidom patches from Nova

Prevent attacks through xml entity expansion etc.

Fixes LP# 1100282

Change-Id: I391531deac122697556c282184c8f8890ea66489

What I think: I know that replacement strings are specially used in cases when the things change on different runs... although it's also a shield to cases where we depend on external fake files (which could be changed and we need to make it less harm when it happens) and generic*. so I suggested few %replacement to be included.

Add API Sample tests for Snapshots extension.

Partially implements blueprint nova-api-samples
Modifies fakes to produce a real timestamp
Fixes bug 1126211

"}, {'account_id': 5313, 'date': '2013-02-26 16:59:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2013-02-26 17:14:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-02-26 17:30:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Looking at this closer, I don't think this is the right approach. This "missing configuration" situation arises when the user takes _your_ default values of None for these two parameters. Can't you provide sane defaults for those?'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-26 17:44:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/22907/4/check/gate-nova-pep8/21593 : SUCCESS

- http://logs.openstack.org/22907/4/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/5533 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/22907/4/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/5252 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/22907/4/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/10229 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/22907/4/check/gate-nova-pylint/8865 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 5313, 'date': '2013-02-26 17:58:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Dan, I thought about that but would prefer that we force the user to make conscious decisions to explicitly set those values. On powervm the images could be rather big especially for AIX so defaulting to something that is might not be mounted on a separate disk could take space from / mount point and crash the system. The idea is that user would need to make a choice at config time on where these big images are safe to put'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-02-26 18:05:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Right, but that runs counter to how everything else works in nova right now.'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-02-26 18:21:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I agree with Dan, the power driver should set defaults for these config parameters. The power driver is no different to other virt drivers in its need for storage of VM disk files. They all manage to provide default locations for this kind of thing, so I think the powervm driver should too. These defaults may not suit every user, but they can trivially change them as desired."}, {'account_id': 5313, 'date': '2013-02-26 18:26:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

In libvirt and hyperv there is not concept of temp directories to fetch the image to nor remote paths to move the image to. It goes directly to cache and from there to the instance path. In powervm we need to move the image to a remote power box, cache is kept there, so not sure there is a precedence in any other driver for these paths. The properties where set to default None intentionally from the beginning for exactly the same reason I posted above, defaults on paths have proven to be dangerous. This patch only attempts to give an early warning when service it starting up so that it is easier to debug. The main issue here was that user forgot to set the paths and started getting some "file or directory not found" errors. Which took forever to debug. This patch attempts to address that'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-02-26 18:27:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

The reason it took forever to debug is because you didn't provide default paths.

Sorry, but I don't think your case differs substantially from the uses in the other drivers. If anything, it is a more reasonable use of a default directory, akin to mktemp()."}, {'account_id': 5313, 'date': '2013-02-26 18:39:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Dan and Daniel, I'm giving you objective reasons why powervm needs not defaults paths, we are being proactive to make sure customers get the best experience. I honestly don't think any other driver cares too much about making sure they don't brake the host with a full drive. In my experience the default will be used most of the time, things will appear to work magically and then, power system will be down, this will also happen very fast, since VIOS (AIX) default install leaves very little space for / mount point. This will mean very bad first impression on Open Stack out of the shop."}, {'account_id': 5371, 'date': '2013-02-26 18:47:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Perhaps we could use default paths but throw a LOG.warn or LOG.info informing them they likely need to change the remote image path. This seems to be the critical setting, as we can use the same local image path as the other drivers tend to use (/var/lib/nova/{images,instances/_base}.)

I would add that David does have a valid point. The reason we left them with default None was they are critical configuration options that need to be consciously set. I tried to set them as required=True as a quick test, but that doesn't seem to be enforced anywhere."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-02-26 18:50:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Most of the values are critical and require thought by the admin for a functioning system. Saying that these are any different makes no sense to me.

I also don't think that logging warning messages if they are equal to the defaults makes any sense. That would imply that the defaults are not sane, which is the whole point."}, {'account_id': 4601, 'date': '2013-02-26 18:53:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

I don't think the exception handling are useful because it will fail anyway in case the paths are not valid."}, {'account_id': 5313, 'date': '2013-02-26 19:00:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Tiago, yes you are right they fail anyways I have seen this, the exception is just an attempt to make user aware there is a problem early and simplify debugging as errors we get don't mention the root cause is the config options not being set. I definitely don't think we should default at all from reasons state it above."}, {'account_id': 4601, 'date': '2013-02-26 19:02:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

So, LOG.debug or LOG.warn can be useful for this case.'}, {'account_id': 5313, 'date': '2013-02-26 19:12:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Tiago, do you care if they get defaulted? What is your take on that'}, {'account_id': 4601, 'date': '2013-02-26 19:19:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

The default values can be an indication of how it can be configured as an example. So I think it's fine."}, {'account_id': 5313, 'date': '2013-02-26 20:39:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I found a suitable default for powervm_img_remote_path that at least will not take power system down. Any suggestions for default on powervm_img_local_path? This will be were images a fetch to from glance'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2013-02-26 20:43:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I think we could do the same as what the other drivers do for the local path, something like /var/lib/nova/{images,instances/_base} like what Matt suggested in his comment earlier.'}, {'account_id': 5313, 'date': '2013-02-26 22:50:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 5313, 'date': '2013-02-26 22:54:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-27 00:35:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed.  For information on how to proceed, see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GerritJenkinsGithub#Test_Failures

"}, {'account_id': 4601, 'date': '2013-02-27 02:19:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

DocImpact in the commit message."}, {'account_id': 5313, 'date': '2013-02-27 03:01:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

commit_message:
Makes sure required powervm config options are set

Fixes bug 1132931

Defaulting values of powervm_img_local_path and
powervm_img_remote_path configuration options.

Change-Id: I310422bccb84fc0ae12e43b06b4d85e683a91daf

commit_message:
Add basic image filtering tests

* Add service method: detailed listing
* Add test case: filtering by name
* Add test case: filtering by size (min, max)
* Add test case: filter by disk format
* Add test case: filter by container_type
* Add test case: Ordering by size

Partially fixes bug #1086590.

commit_message:
Allow to specify segment container

Fix bug 1110924

Add segment container option as part of 'swift upload -S'. If this
option is omitted, the segments will go to <container>_segments.

Example:
$ swift upload c1 obj1 -S 1 -C user_segments

Please check swift upload --help for more details

Change-Id: Ib71aae322485d8d3ac89916d37ebcac053f49e3b

commit_message:
Fix retrieval of shared networks

Bug 1130171

This patch adds a new tag_scope, 'shared', in order to allow
the NVP plugin to retrieve also shared networks from NVP when
listing networks. This way it won't appear as Quantum has a
network without a corresponding lswitch in NVP

Change-Id: I24f950d54c0b9e582c92e8008e75ebd00f6c9fe3

commit_message:
zmq: parse receiver CLI opts in main

We shouldn't be parsing options from sys.argv() unless the main function
is being run.

Change-Id: Id6bae72b80ce35721f02323a7bf7713132a49ac9

commit_message:
NVP Router: Do no perfom SNAT on E-W traffic

Bug 1130053

This patch ensures 'No Snat' rules are enforced in order to avoid source
natting on east-west traffic.

Change-Id: I967e72e7b6bc8e2763c0fbdf6deeafb43ff27f54

commit_message:
Don't use sudo in base.

Install.d hooks are already root, we don't need plain sudo there.

Change-Id: I69747049b2f5f649eb503a24487bbb3a4151ae21

commit_message:
change pip requires to <2.0.0 to try to fix break

the pip requires had <2.0, but with an actual 2.0.0 out there this
doesn't seem good enough. 2.0.0 is full of syntax errors.

Fixes bug 1134163

Change-Id: Ib5e90576739454bcdbfcd5e25b9e5902347b51ca

@michael, the issue is we've got a consistency problem now. If people got to this point one way, they'll have 43 character columns. If they got here another way, they'll have 39 character columns (this was because an update to an old migration happened incorrectly). I really think we need to ensure that no matter how they get to this migration the resultant version needs to look the same."}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2013-02-27 18:05:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Revert IP Address column length to 39

In change I35d4565389d03fce86103289cf6447f824efeba0 we changed the cidr/ip
address column size to 43 to be able to support ipv6 cidr values, although ips
doesn't need that much space so we're reverting it to keep it consistent.

Change-Id: Icd2d727fd0733ee0db23c1fa431df4b982cae7b4

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-24 23:21:59.000000000', 'message': "Fix row striping when datatables are filtered

Bootstrap uses nth-child(2n+1) to stripe tables, but this doesn't
take into account hidden rows. tablesorter's zebra plugin can apply
odd/even classes based on the actual visible rows, so allow these
classes to override the default bootstrap style when they're set.

Fixes bug #1119069

Change-Id: Ie47313a8659226945871be8165c75edee169e816
"}]
commit_message:
Fix row striping when datatables are filtered

Bootstrap uses nth-child(2n+1) to stripe tables, but this doesn't
take into account hidden rows. tablesorter's zebra plugin can apply
odd/even classes based on the actual visible rows, so allow these
classes to override the default bootstrap style when they're set.

Fixes bug #1119069

Change-Id: Ie47313a8659226945871be8165c75edee169e816

subject: Fix a TypeError when working in a Folsom env.

'}, {'account_id': 4978, 'date': '2013-02-15 13:45:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I can confirm this fixes the problem as described in the bug report.

I wonder if it is a valid bug though, as it fixes an interaction with an old keystone client. To reproduce the bug, in addition to setting up a Folsom environment I also had to switch the keystone client to use the 0.1.3 version (0.2.0 is fine). My understanding is that the clients are backwards-compatible so that it's always ok to use the master version.

https://github.com/openstack/python-keystoneclient/commit/56a4e4bd7da1353684d34e5a9817b88501e41d8c - original_ip attribute added to the client"}, {'account_id': 4264, 'date': '2013-02-15 16:45:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Well, this error occurs e.g. if you install a OpenStack Folsom on Fedora and use Horizon from Grizzly.

It won't harm, to have this workaround."}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2013-02-15 20:05:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

That'll work,  but a TODO comment to remove it in H would be ideal. Also, ultimately isn't this issue more a question of the version of keystoneclient, not the version of keystone? I'm still not sure what the "official" position is about adding changes that depend on a more recent novaclient.

But I think any code needs to at least be compatible with the client version in pip-requires - which means either making the change backwards compatible or updating the minimum version in pip-requires. I'd prefer the latter to keep the code clean. I don't see a reason to support client versions below what will be eventually shipped with Grizzly, but I'm not that familiar with the release process.'}, {'account_id': 4978, 'date': '2013-02-21 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Good point Kieran, thanks for the rview. I'll update the pip-requires version."}, {'account_id': 4978, 'date': '2013-02-21 10:21:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 4978, 'date': '2013-02-21 10:23:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Changed to INFO level logging for main cinder-backup operations

Changed create backup, restore backup and delete backup operations to
log key operations at INFO level instead of DEBUG level (so environments
like devstack see main operations by default).

Fixes bug: 1132788

Change-Id: I3b4600be8fbc1869054f81752c92936d55395185

commit_message:
Update v2 image update for JSON Schema draft 10

* Add support for JSON Schema Draft 10
* Remain backwards-compatibile with the superseded Draft 4
* Fixes bug 1102476

Change-Id: I43d79fdade0d2bc6f5f1e67d70f89cebff29c011

'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2013-02-27 17:43:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (4 inline comments)

some new comments.  

in my reviews, i've several times seen typos that seem to imply that there hasn't been much testing here.  If this was a completely new feature that did not affect existing code (e.g., lbaas) I'd be less worried, but this patch is very complex and may put even our core L3 + floating Ip use cases at risk, especially since we don't have much/any multi-node tests.

I don't see any other core reviews on this patch, so i'm nervous about whether this is getting any much testing, much less real multi-node testing.  At this point in the release cycle, our first rule needs to be "do no harm" to existing functionality, so the testing bar needs to be quite high.  

Tonight is the deadline for merging this feature without an FFE.  If we decide to ask for an FFE we need to know we have dedicated core reviewers and extremely high confidence that this doesn't break existing functionality.  I must admit, this patch is so complex I don't fully have my head wrapped around it, so I personally can't provide that confidence.'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2013-02-27 17:43:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2013-02-27 17:43:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: (3 inline comments)

I am on a half way of testing.
I tested dhcp scheduler with 3 nodes. It works well as far as I tested.

- I created 6 networks and the networks are hosted by three dhcp-agents.
- dhcp-agent-network-add and dhcp-agent-network-delete also works well. When network added to dhcp-agent, dnsmasq started and when  a assigned network is removed, dnsmasq stopped as I expected.
- IP address for an instance is successfully leased even when dhcp-agent hosting the network is switched (by dhcp-agent-network-add/delete)

It would be convenient if a command which displays all bindings for all networks and all agents. During the test, I feel frustrated with net-dhcp-agent-list and dhcp-agent-list since both commands requires an argument agent_id or network_id/name.

scheduling a network to a dhcp-agent is done when the network is created, so dhcp-agent hosts networks where enable_dhcp is False. It feel a little confusing.

(Finally, I apologize for the delay of testing. My base machine for testing had a trouble with disks...)'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2013-02-27 17:43:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: (1 inline comment)

some nits.'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2013-02-27 17:43:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

Hi, gongysh,

I tested with two dhcp agents and two l3 agents.

Tested case: 
1. dhcp-agent-network-add/remove
2. l3-agent-router-add/remove
3. update dhcp/l3 agent --admin_state_up False

That all works for me.

But I found when some errors raise on l3 agent, the l3 agent will full sync the routers from server. Then non-hosted routers(Those routers just created, didn't add any interface, so those routers are non-hosted) will host on that failure l3 agent.

Check the code, I think reason was in sync routers callback 'L3RpcCallbackMixin.sync_routers' will call 'plugin.auto_schedule_routers'. That hosts all non-hosted router to the caller l3 agent."}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2013-02-27 17:43:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

my test with multi hosts works well. And no more question. Hope jenkins back. Thank, Alex'}, {'account_id': 6623, 'date': '2013-02-27 17:43:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: (4 inline comments)

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-27 17:43:19.000000000', 'message': 'Add scheduling feature basing on agent management extension

3rd part of blueprint quantum-scheduler

1. Allow networks to be hosted by certain dhcp agents.
Network to dhcp agent is a
many to many relationship. Provide a simple
scheduler to schedule a network randomly
to an active dhcp agent when a network or port is created.
2. Allow admin user to (de)schedule network to a
certain dhcp agent manually.
3. Allow routers to be hosted by certain l3 agents.
Router to l3 agent is a many to many relationship.
Provide a simple scheduler to
schedule a router to l3 agent if the router is not
scheduled when the router is created or updated.
4. One L3 agent hosting a router plays default role,
other L3 agents hosting the same router are in colocated mode.
5. Auto schedule networks and routers to agents when agents
start.
6. Only support ovs plugin at this point

Change-Id: Iddec3ea9d4c0fe2d51a59f7db47145722fc5a1cd
'}, {'created': '2013-02-27 17:43:19.000000000', 'message': 'Add scheduling feature basing on agent management extension

3. Allow routers to be hosted by certain l3 agents.
Router to l3 agent is a many to many relationship.
Provide a simple scheduler to
schedule a router to l3 agent if the router is not
scheduled when the router is created or updated.
4. One L3 agent hosting a router plays default role,
other L3 agents hosting the same router are in colocated mode.
5. Auto schedule networks and routers to agents when agents
start.
6. Only support ovs plugin at this point

Change-Id: Iddec3ea9d4c0fe2d51a59f7db47145722fc5a1cd

5. Auto schedule networks and routers to agents when agents
start.
6. Only support ovs plugin at this point

Change-Id: Iddec3ea9d4c0fe2d51a59f7db47145722fc5a1cd

commit_message:
Add scheduling feature basing on agent management extension

3rd part of blueprint quantum-scheduler

1. Allow networks to be hosted by certain dhcp agents.
Network to dhcp agent is a
many to many relationship. Provide a simple
scheduler to schedule a network randomly
to an active dhcp agent when a network or port is created.
2. Allow admin user to (de)schedule network to a
certain dhcp agent manually.
3. Allow routers to be hosted by a certain l3 agent.
Router to l3 agent is a many to one relationship.
Provide a simple scheduler to
schedule a router to l3 agent if the router is not
scheduled when the router is  updated.
4. Auto schedule networks and routers to agents when agents
start.
5. Only support ovs plugin at this point

Change-Id: Iddec3ea9d4c0fe2d51a59f7db47145722fc5a1cd

commit_message:
Set state_path to quantum.conf

This change is required to make quantum security groups support of
OVS/LinuxBridge plugins work.

Previously state_path was configured in each agent config files in
Quantum, but it is moved to quantum.conf. This change follows it.

Change-Id: I290dc98878661375cf8a31a53d857433de0e5462

commit_message:
Standardises expected exception layout

Standardises how we handle expected exceptions to use
assertRaise rather than using try/except/else

Fixes bug 1132577

Change-Id: Idfefe4c9337e9b832d34a490da21ac32ec65edd1

[{'created': '2013-02-26 19:43:32.000000000', 'message': 'Move the swift.1 manpage to python-swiftclient

When someone split away python-swiftclient, he left behind the
client manpage.

Apparently all we need now is to delete it from swift and
add it to python-swiftclient. Except that of course the releases
have to be synchronized somehow or else files conflict.

Change-Id: I8b5f7b5557c28818048d8941df36473dacfb1d57
'}]
commit_message:
Move the swift.1 manpage to python-swiftclient

When someone split away python-swiftclient, he left behind the
client manpage.

Apparently all we need now is to delete it from swift and
add it to python-swiftclient. Except that of course the releases
have to be synchronized somehow or else files conflict.

Change-Id: I8b5f7b5557c28818048d8941df36473dacfb1d57

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-11 20:27:33.000000000', 'message': "Catch KeyError exception as early as possible when there is no matching data on the server.

When the server does not have any data matching the requested response_key, it can still return
successfully. A subsequent lookup in the returned data throws a KeyError exception. The simple
fix for this is to catch the KeyError exception and return an empty list. An empty list, rather
than None, is required because the calling code expects an iterable. The exception is caught
as early as possible after the server returns from the GET request. The end result is that the
CLI user sees an empty result when the requested data doesn't exist on the server. Prior to
this fix the keyError exception was propagated all the way to the user, causing a confusing
message to be printed.

Fixes bug #1111972

Change-Id: Ic7ba53f110ff2424186caf38ddf2fabd549dc53e
"}]
commit_message:
Catch KeyError exception as early as possible when there is no matching data on the server.

When the server does not have any data matching the requested response_key, it can still return
successfully. A subsequent lookup in the returned data throws a KeyError exception. The simple
fix for this is to catch the KeyError exception and return an empty list. An empty list, rather
than None, is required because the calling code expects an iterable. The exception is caught
as early as possible after the server returns from the GET request. The end result is that the
CLI user sees an empty result when the requested data doesn't exist on the server. Prior to
this fix the keyError exception was propagated all the way to the user, causing a confusing
message to be printed.

Fixes bug #1111972

Change-Id: Ic7ba53f110ff2424186caf38ddf2fabd549dc53e

this resource created, otherwise the resource will not be functional

commit_message:
Add waitcondition to loadbalancer nested template

We want to ensure the LB instance has fully launched before declaring
this resource created, otherwise the resource will not be functional
and attempts to modify config via metadata updates will fail

Change-Id: I879c21302f1c3a75a567d959fc2e398c7bfc3f65

commit_message:
Add cache=swift.cache for authtoken example.

- Things swill go badly with swift if we leave the default to authtoken
  to use its own memcache cache connection based python-memcache c based
  binding.

Change-Id: I293b875acdcb06e5a7a0cfa9a9bb5d7678675da0

commit_message:
feat(Kernel): Demonstrate wiring up endpoints

Add just enough code to show how the kernel might use endpoint controllers
as the uniform interface between transport and storage drivers.

Change-Id: Id359986a4e45850266e64b06dae4544b52c8f93c
Implements: blueprint endpoints

commit_message:
Use multiple locations for elements dir.

Using ELEMENTS_DIR env variable, you can specify multiple dirs containint your elements.
It must be a ":" separated elements list.

When an element is seen in one of those lists, it will be chosen and will continue with the next element.

Change-Id: I18eca27d943139cd6ca1ebd232b419e502d7b048

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-26 18:25:54.000000000', 'message': "Add swift.1

This commit add the upstream man page byte-for-byte. The page is
very ugly and is to be revised, but for now let's not make the
commit more complex than necessary.

The relocation is not yet upstream, but this is purely for the
scheduling reasons. I do not expect any trouble there.

Change-Id: I24f238501589db940574eac61b89a1422fe2fd77
Resolves: rhbz#904353
"}, {'created': '2013-02-26 19:49:23.000000000', 'message': 'Add client man page swift.1

This is the byte-by-byte copy of swift.1 that was left behind
in the main Swift package when python-swiftclient was split away.
Apparently there is absolutely nothing to be changed in setup.py
and the distribution packagers are supposed to pick the page as-is
using their packaging systems.

Change-Id: I24f238501589db940574eac61b89a1422fe2fd77
'}]
commit_message:
Add client man page swift.1

This is the byte-by-byte copy of swift.1 that was left behind
in the main Swift package when python-swiftclient was split away.
Apparently there is absolutely nothing to be changed in setup.py
and the distribution packagers are supposed to pick the page as-is
using their packaging systems.

Change-Id: I24f238501589db940574eac61b89a1422fe2fd77

commit_message:
Limit amount of fixed ips per port

Fixes bug 1100476

The patch also updates the quantum configuration file to
contain the following:
 - max number of host routes
 - max number of dns servers

Change-Id: Ic5d90034b0231687dfbde8fc65780ab52222c0fd

'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-01-29 16:54:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Do not merge

(1 inline comment)

pending API docs; see the openstack/identity-api project. I'm also curious what the use case is for this?

As-is, this needs to be documented as an extension to v2.0 which I would advise against. Instead, propose this as a new resource on v3: 

  https://github.com/openstack/identity-api/blob/master/openstack-identity-api/src/markdown/identity-api-v3.md

v3 currently supports:

- List user's roles on project:
  GET /projects/{project_id}/users/{user_id}/roles

- Check if user has role on project:
  HEAD /projects/{project_id}/users/{user_id}/roles/{role_id}

- List group's roles on project:
  GET /projects/{project_id}/groups/{group_id}/roles

- Check if group has role on project:
  HEAD /projects/{project_id}/groups/{group_id}/roles/{role_id}

- List user's roles on domain:
  GET /domains/{domain_id}/users/{user_id}/roles

- Check if user has role on domain:
  HEAD /domains/{domain_id}/users/{user_id}/roles/{role_id}

- List group's roles on domain:
  GET /domains/{domain_id}/groups/{group_id}/roles/{role_id}

- Check if group has role on domain:
  HEAD /domains/{domain_id}/groups/{group_id}/roles

To achieve feature parity for listing users/groups, you'd just need to add four calls:

- List users with role on project:
  GET /projects/{project_id}/roles/{role_id}/users

- List groups with roles on project:
  GET /projects/{project_id}/roles/{role_id}/groups

- List users with roles on domain:
  GET /domains/{domain_id}/roles/{role_id}/users

- List groups with roles on domain:
  GET /domains/{domain_id}/roles/{role_id}/groups"}, {'account_id': 2998, 'date': '2013-02-01 15:20:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-02-01 15:20:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

New patchset patch-id matches previous patchset, but commit message has changed.'}, {'account_id': 2998, 'date': '2013-02-01 15:21:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Use case is quite simple. I'd been working on Openstack management UI, the customer wanted to see who exactly had certain roles in certain projects. I've been using API v2.

I can fetch users and iterate through them on client site or have this work done on server side. I had strong feeling that by some mistake Keystone does not implement this kind of sorting for /users/ resource.

At Launchpad I found an issue for this, there were 3 others who wanted this feature, and the issue had status Triaged.

Why have 4 resources added when we need small adding to an existing resource?"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-01 16:29:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed.  For information on how to proceed, see http://wiki.openstack.org/GerritJenkinsGithub#Test_Failures

"}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-02-01 23:09:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

@Axlexander, because it's an obviously useful but undocumented feature being introduced to an API that's about to be deprecated. I'd love to see the feature documented and carried forward as part of Identity API v3"}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-02-01 23:10:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

if you remove the change to controllers here, i'd be happy to unblock until we get it documented and properly exposed on v3"}, {'account_id': 2998, 'date': '2013-02-04 16:06:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-02-04 16:27:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

As I mentioned above, a query string is not the proper way to implement this feature in the v3 API. On top of that, the term 'tenant' is not used in v3. Please revert the change to controllers until we get this properly documented with an agreed-upon API in the openstack/identity-api project."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-04 17:34:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Adds list of users with a role in a tenant

Added list_users_with_role_in_tenant() to sql, kvs and ldap
identity backends. Added processing of GET arguments 'role' and
'tenant' to controllers. Supplied test for backends.

Change-Id: I68fa73b3baeda021ac72ef010b5b9ac37e09b6fe
Fixes: bug #1070544
DocImpact

[{'created': '2013-02-19 21:19:06.000000000', 'message': 'Sync RPC from oslo.

Highlights:
* Add cinder-rpc-zmq-receiver
* ZeroMQ stability fixes.
* Faster AMQP messaging.
* Faster ZeroMQ messaging.
* RPC Envelope support
* Switch to oslo-config
* Various bug-fixes.
* TTL support for AMQP.
* AMQP mirrored queues support.

Change-Id: Ic68d0c0b81d44547e2c46082a4a9a5e097e05829
'}]
commit_message:
Sync RPC from oslo.

Highlights:
* Add cinder-rpc-zmq-receiver
* ZeroMQ stability fixes.
* Faster AMQP messaging.
* Faster ZeroMQ messaging.
* RPC Envelope support
* Switch to oslo-config
* Various bug-fixes.
* TTL support for AMQP.
* AMQP mirrored queues support.

Change-Id: Ic68d0c0b81d44547e2c46082a4a9a5e097e05829

[{'created': '2013-02-19 03:49:13.000000000', 'message': 'Sometimes use quantum for SecurityGroup

This implements the following properties in AWS::EC2::SecurityGroup
- VpcId
- SecurityGroupEgress

If VpcId is specified, completely separate code paths
are used which make quantum calls instead of nova calls.

This implements blueprint quantum-security-group

Change-Id: I730aa609eb7919870c8546239916e000731b8d0a
'}]
commit_message:
Sometimes use quantum for SecurityGroup

This implements the following properties in AWS::EC2::SecurityGroup
- VpcId
- SecurityGroupEgress

If VpcId is specified, completely separate code paths
are used which make quantum calls instead of nova calls.

This implements blueprint quantum-security-group

Change-Id: I730aa609eb7919870c8546239916e000731b8d0a

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/22135/3/check/gate-tempest-pep8/2201 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/22135/3/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/3908 : SUCCESS

- http://logs.openstack.org/22135/3/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum-full/449 : FAILURE (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 5196, 'date': '2013-02-19 16:26:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

lgtm, but I'd prefer that you call the file something else like xml_utils.py to be a bit more descriptive about what it does xml is a bit too generic. Also, I agree with moving the file out of compute, but I think that the right place for the file is in tempest/common or tempest/common/utils."}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-02-19 16:45:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Why we have modules in the tempest/ and in tempest/common too ?
One of them is illogical IMHO, choose which one.

Until the xml name has only one function, we do not need to add any distinguishing part.

We should also consider applying rule about do not have two module/package with same name in the source tree.'}, {'account_id': 5196, 'date': '2013-02-19 17:14:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I've always viewed the modules in tempest as things that were required or contained base classes (like config, clients, test, etc...) and tempest.common is were you put modules that were (or could) be used in multiple places but aren't as critical. Mostly modules that are there to mostly remove code duplication (like oslo just on the tempest scale). IMO the methods in this file fit in the latter description so they belong in tempest.common.

But, I don't think this was ever a hard and fast rule about the 2 locations, (It was probably just my perception) but I feel that there should be a separation between the 2, I don't think piling everything into the tempest dir is the right solution.

As for the filename you're right about it, I just felt that xml was too generic of a filename. But, I guess it's far better than common.py which it was before, so it'll probably be fine as is."}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-02-19 18:35:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

This "common" directory is very frequent visible in java sources.

I checked the Python 2.7.3 source for reference, and I did find such directory. 

When java guys using this name, they do not have any java file in the same level just directories.

java has different namespace rules and organization guidelines than python.

In java you can create just one public class in file, and you must use the same name as the file name.

If you do the same thing In python, you creates 2 namespaces instead of single one. 
 

In python noramlly every package, has special moudule __init__ , it is (sometimes) usable for base type creation, but you had to be very careful what kind of import do you do in these files, core python and external imports are safe.'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-02-19 18:50:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

This "common" directory is very frequent visible in java sources.

I checked the Python 2.7.3 source for reference, and I did NOT find such directory.

When java guys using this name, they do not have any java file in the same level, just directories.

java has different namespace rules and organization guidelines than python.

In java you can create just one public class in file, and you must use the same name as the file name.

If you do the same thing In python, you creates 2 namespaces instead of single one.

In python noramlly every package, has special moudule __init__ , it is (sometimes) usable for base type creation, but you had to be very careful what kind of import do you do in these files, core python and external imports are safe.

If we apply the just module import rule, probably the unsafe import usage will not work in the __init__.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-02-27 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-02-27 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

Instead of adding this, I'd rather see the code fixed to use the service catalog to discover what API to use."}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2013-02-16 23:01:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I agree that "make it work" flags are bad.

In fact, I'm confident we already have service catalog lookup working for glance. IIRC we didn't know what to do with multiple glance entries, so we just use the first. Is it somehow possible to detect API version from the catalog entry?'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-02-18 18:09:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

That's a good question, Matt Treinish is going to take a stab at if there is a service catalog discovery path here that would make sense."}, {'account_id': 5196, 'date': '2013-02-19 22:27:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Looking at the glance entries in the service catalog there isn't a good way to do the version discovery. I wasn't able to find any version information for glance in the service catalog or in the endpoints. This is also consistent with glanceclient, which takes in a a version param for Client(). It then uses that to import the right client modules for either v1 or v2.

For H I'll look into cleaning this up in glance to make the available api versions discoverable."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2013-02-19 23:23:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Matthew - the available glance versions are discoverable by issuing a GET / against the glance service.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-02-27 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

commit_message:
Add glance_api_version configuration option

Provide a configuration option to set the default version of Glance
APIs to use when accessing the image services APIs to allow newer
versions to be utilized as the glanceclient is update.

implements blueprint configurable-glance-api-version

Change-Id: I6c843ebb4f3b548e562c551910aa629ab5b06bf2

commit_message:
Add Support for Cinder Volume migration

* Adds support for cinder volume migration during live block migration
* Uses symlinks in instance-xx dir to cinder volume /dev/disk/by-path
* Copies currently attached volumes to new volumes specified using
  --block-device-mapping flag for "nova live-migration" command

Blueprint migrate-volume-block-migration

Change-Id: Ia605cd49692080f6a77314f904b48bc31cbab227

commit_message:
pin django to 1.4.x stream

django 1.5 just released in the last hour, and there is a
compatibility issue with it and horizon causing gate failures.

Pin this so that we can get back to business and let the horizon
team address django 1.5 when it makes sense to them.

Change-Id: I6ddf9623f8a4719b1cb82b118c1876373051fd28
(cherry picked from commit 0d53dc7063003fa7f02c030fd1631e0cd553d22a)

commit_message:
add database drivers for whitebox testing

if you are running this in a venv environment, the whitebox tests
don't actually run because there are no db drivers. Let's fix that.

Change-Id: I0524c0e0f54350f54f949aeb48b2ba23e0803f75

commit_message:
Catching new exception while disassociating a disassociated floating ip

Because the response of disassociating floating ip api will be
changed(bug #1129719), so the tempest codes need to be updated synchronically.

Change-Id: Ie25ed338dda01cf5e52982abae9ea85386a293a9

commit_message:
Run os-config-applier immediatley on first boot:

ensure os-config-applier runs before other first
boot scripts which may depend on config being in place.

Change-Id: Ic49fb965370c676de53ef6eb4094bf74340f56ec

subject: Revert "Update sample_data.sh to match docs"
messages: [{'account_id': 6850, 'date': '2013-02-27 03:49:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Abandoned\n\nI'll submit a patch for this script instead of a revert request"}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-27 03:08:17.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "Update sample_data.sh to match docs"

There are a number of problems with this change:
It removes support for Quantum, I'm not sure why?

You used to be able to set SERVICE_PASSWORD and ADMIN_PASSWORD, now the passwords are hard-coded in.

It doesn't create the Member role, this breaks Horizon, when you go to "Projects" and try to modify users, you get an error because it says there is no default Role.

This reverts commit d6f7cbc484868bdec3eeb9d4b0f45b10ce536e79'}]
commit_message:
Revert "Update sample_data.sh to match docs"

There are a number of problems with this change:
It removes support for Quantum, I'm not sure why?

You used to be able to set SERVICE_PASSWORD and ADMIN_PASSWORD, now the passwords are hard-coded in.

It doesn't create the Member role, this breaks Horizon, when you go to "Projects" and try to modify users, you get an error because it says there is no default Role.

This reverts commit d6f7cbc484868bdec3eeb9d4b0f45b10ce536e79

Bug 1130211

This patch allows for using multiple layer-3 gateways leveraging the
provider networks extension.

commit_message:
Add --kernel and --ramdisk to image-create.

Currently we need to specify both "--property kernel_id=<ID>" and "--property
ramdisk_id=<ID>" when uploading the root fs image of linux, and that is not
easy-to-use because we cannot specify these parameters by names.

This patch adds --kernel and --ramdisk options to "glance image-create"
command, and we can specify kernel and ramdisk by these image name.

Fixes bug 1093380

Change-Id: I5102bcf28fa9ec450728cecc4d90f259c9982f85

commit_message:
Add debug level logs for TempAuth.authorize.

The function authorize in tempauth.py and keysthoneauth.py is very
important and frequently called in swift. But authorize in tempauth
seems hard to debug with nearly no logs here.

Change-Id: I3300a5a8d02743ff76e2ff86c51338ca24ddddcb
Fixes: bug #1129769

messages:
[{'account_id': 330, 'date': '2013-02-15 00:04:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2013-02-15 00:08:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-02-15 00:16:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

One suggestion (key instead of Schwartzian-transform-by-hand).'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2013-02-15 00:26:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

This is neat!

I was wonderin' - maybe go ahead and call 'sort_nodes_by_timing' just 'sort_nodes' and let a config option dictate the node sort strategy?  Continue to support the existing shuffle behavior, and possibly new ideas in the future?

The reason I ask is cause the node timing seems to only base on the time to make the connection, not the time to first byte (am I wrong here?).  I know shuffle was originally added mainly for the container servers, where the primary node would get busy and take awhile to open up and stat the db, but if some weird network topology left a single node consistently slightly closer it could be a bit of a regression where all the requests get pinned to a single db and others are just waiting?

Again supporting the old strategy with a config and then doing some benchmarking might be a good idea... 

darrel has some other ideas too that might be better of both worlds, maybe there's more to come on this patch :D"}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-02-15 00:42:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

http://wiki.python.org/moin/HowTo/Sorting/ claims Python's sorting is stable.  So if you shuffle, then sort like

  random.shuffle(nodes)
  return sorted(nodes, key=lambda n: round(self.node_timings.get(n['ip'], 0.0), 3))

Then you'll get the nice load evening between, say, container servers, when their connection times are within one millisecond of each other.  (This is simpler than the "binning" crap I was talking about in the office.)'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-02-15 00:45:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

You may want to consider "unknown" as -1.0 in this case, though, since otherwise "unknown" will look the same as any known timing < 1.0, which is undesirable.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-15 01:33:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/22006/3/check/gate-swift-pep8/1540 : SUCCESS

- http://logs.openstack.org/22006/3/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/2646 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-02-15 01:48:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

++ on the suggestions of genericizing names, config options for old-way vs. this-way (vs. future-ways).

Not so sure on the shuffle+sort thing, seems unnecessary for timings that'll change pretty often and probably shuffle themselves request to request.

I do worry that if a node has a "bad day" so to speak, it'll never get used again unless some other node has an even worse request -- unless I'm reading something wrong.

The 'make a list of t, n', 'sort', 'make a list of just n' seems it could be clearer and quicker as:

    return sorted(nodes, key=lambda n: self.node_timings.get(n['ip'], 0))

If you store an expiration time for the timings:

    now = time()

    def key_func(node):
        timing, expires = self.node_timings.get(n['ip'], (0, 0))
        return timing if expires > now else 0

    return sorted(nodes, key=key_func)


"All my log files start with #!/usr/bin/less" -- M. Barton'}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2013-02-15 07:17:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

This is an important, yet risky feature. 

Please add a mechanism for self.node_timings to also reduce - otherwise you will get very busy nodes and others which do nothing due to the fact that they timed out previously

For example a sudden network hiccup will set a bunch of servers to timeout and from that moment on these servers will no longer participate in the service as no requests will come to them. 

This can be done by picking a random node and reducing its timing. For example:
new_timing = old_timing*0.8 



From the same reason, please change the timing of servers gradually and not at once. such that you use a unction like: new_timing = old_timing*0.9 + current_timing*0.1

These two mechanisms together should amount for a less aggressive, yet sufficiently dynamic change in the system.  
Some experimentation may be needed to define the right values for the 0.8 and 0.9 mentioned above.'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2013-02-18 15:54:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2013-02-18 16:11:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2013-02-18 16:21:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2013-02-18 16:57:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Deciding the timing based on a single measurement is not a stable or reliable mechanism.
Network latency is not a stable function of distance and variance is extremely high.
Use many measurements instead of one. 
The easiest way to achieve that is something like: 
    new_time = old_time*0.9+new_time*0.1   

Expiring timing measurements collected over time is also not a great way - see suggested alternative in previous review.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-18 17:19:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/22006/6/check/gate-swift-pep8/1546 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/22006/6/check/gate-swift-docs/1401 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/22006/6/check/gate-swift-python26/1648 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/22006/6/check/gate-swift-python27/1651 : SUCCESS

- http://logs.openstack.org/22006/6/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/7951 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/22006/6/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/3272 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-02-18 19:50:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

@David: I'm not sure that's a problem with the initial shuffle and rounding (connect times within one millisecond are considered equal).

IIRC, connection timeouts don't "poison" nodes (that node's timing data is left alone).  If a random slow-but-successful connection happens, that node *will* be penalized until the age-out, when a fresh attempt will be made.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-02-19 15:54:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

In _connect_put_node you pass a node_timing_updator (always set to self.app.set_node_timing) whereas everywhere else you just use self.app.set_node_timing. Just an experiment not fully unwound?


"He's an arborsexual.' -- S. Simpson'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-02-19 17:25:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

@gholt: Could it be related to _connect_put_node running in a spawned greenlet?  It looks like self.app.logger.thread_locals is also passed in (and then assigned back into self.app.logger.thread_locals in _connect_put_node), so I guess the spawned greenthread running _connect_put_node must have trouble getting at self.app?'}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2013-02-19 18:10:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

@Darrell: networks and servers offer response times with extremely high variation when considering a single request processing time across the network. 

Even if server A is on average offering a preferable timing compared to server B. If you pick one single request from each one and compare the two (during a rush hour) you may not be doing much better than random choice between them. 

Just as a silly example, consider a case where a server have average timing of T ms but also have 10% of its requests taking 2*T ms.  A second server may have an average service of 1.5*T ms without variation. after several requests to the first server you will hit a 2*T request and move to the second server until 5 minuets later...

You can see that shuffling and rounding would not help here unless T is at the sub-millisecond range in which case we are back to standard randomization - as we do today.'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2013-02-19 18:27:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2013-02-19 18:29:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

I pulled out the parameter to _connect_put_node. It was part of an idea that doesn't seem needed. Thanks for the catch."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-19 19:22:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-02-27 00:37:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

While I do think the single-sample timing measurement is too simplistic, I do like a couple things about this patch:

1) it still shuffles by default, so even if the new algorithm turns out to be the worst thing since the Twilight movies, it won't hurt existing clusters; and

2) it introduces a place to experiment with different backend-selection algorithms.

It's enough of an improvement over what was there before that I think it's worth merging."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-27 00:38:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: No score

[{'created': '2013-02-14 23:54:11.000000000', 'message': "timing-based affinity sorting for primary replicas

This changes the way primary replicas are sorted on GET requests.
Previously, replicas were shuffled. Now the replicas are sorted
based on the most recent connection time data to that node.

get_more_nodes() (ie handoffs) is unaffected by this patch because
sorting by affinity would break the durability provided by the current
as-unique-as-possible handoff selection.

Timing data is collected for each node each time the proxy makes a
connection to that node. If timing data for a node doesn't exist, then
it is assumed at 0 (ie will sort earlier) so that timing data can be
collected for that node.

commit_message:
timing-based affinity sorting for primary replicas

This changes the way primary replicas can be sorted on GET requests.
Previously, replicas were shuffled. Now, if configured, the replicas
are sorted based on the most recent connection time data to that node.
This patch adds a config value that changes the sorting method.

get_more_nodes() (ie handoffs) is unaffected by this patch because
sorting by affinity would break the durability provided by the current
as-unique-as-possible handoff selection.

Timing data is collected for each node each time the proxy makes a
connection to that node (IP address). If timing data for a node doesn't
exist, then it is assumed at -1 (ie will sort earlier) so that timing
data can be collected for that node.

Change-Id: I837fa21c3a566b10cce33eb75788665e1d01cd8a

commit_message:
Add migration 021 set_engine_mysql_innodb

Change: I1536c9276bc807aac26849e37556b465e8b5c9eb which added
migration 018 neglected to set the mysql engine to InnoDB
when it added the image_locations table. This commit adds a
new migration to set the image_locations table to the InnoDB
engine.

Change-Id: I935065d8e1929d5df075cc5c7de81793b1dd73a1

commit_message:
Correct docstring for swift.common.ring.utils.build_tier_tree and add
unit test for it.

Some mistakes is in original docstring of that method. There's no unit
test for two methods in swift.common.ring.utils.

Fixes: bug #1070621

Change-Id: I6f4f211ea67d7fb8ccfe659f30bb0f5d394aca6b

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-26 15:05:15.000000000', 'message': 'Correctly mock keystoneclient.Client.auto_token property with Mox

Recent Mox doesn't stub out class properties any more (check
https://code.google.com/p/pymox/issues/detail?id=11), so we have to do
that manually. Avoids the following error:

FAIL: test_get_default_role
(openstack_dashboard.test.api_tests.keystone_tests.RoleAPITests)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/root/Projects/openstack/horizon/openstack_dashboard/test/api_tests/keystone_tests.py", line 76, in test_get_default_role
    keystoneclient = self.stub_keystoneclient()
  File "/root/Projects/openstack/horizon/openstack_dashboard/test/helpers.py", line 280, in stub_keystoneclient
    self.keystoneclient = self.mox.CreateMock(keystone_client.Client)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/mox.py", line 258, in CreateMock
    new_mock = MockObject(class_to_mock, attrs=attrs)

commit_message:
Correctly mock keystoneclient.Client.auto_token property with Mox

Recent Mox doesn't stub out class properties any more (check
https://code.google.com/p/pymox/issues/detail?id=11), so we have to do
that manually. Avoids the following error:

FAIL: test_get_default_role
(openstack_dashboard.test.api_tests.keystone_tests.RoleAPITests)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/root/Projects/openstack/horizon/openstack_dashboard/test/api_tests/keystone_tests.py", line 76, in test_get_default_role
    keystoneclient = self.stub_keystoneclient()
  File "/root/Projects/openstack/horizon/openstack_dashboard/test/helpers.py", line 280, in stub_keystoneclient
    self.keystoneclient = self.mox.CreateMock(keystone_client.Client)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/mox.py", line 258, in CreateMock
    new_mock = MockObject(class_to_mock, attrs=attrs)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/mox.py", line 556, in __init__
    attr = getattr(class_to_mock, method)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/mox.py", line 608, in __getattr__
    raise UnknownMethodCallError(name)
UnknownMethodCallError: Method called is not a member of the object: Method called is not a member of the object: auth_token
>>  raise UnknownMethodCallError('auth_token')

Change-Id: I54fd0de298dc66344470147d9bcec6b62baf8297
