revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-22 21:17:53.000000000', 'message': "Improve error message for missing endpoint

Horizon logs an error when it wants an endpoint
that the client can't find, but the error does not
say which endpoint is missing. This change includes
more details in the error message to make debugging
from the horizon logs easier.

Change-Id: I6f0aacd469500238f13a2178a220268d86d31fe5
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Improve error message for missing endpoint

Horizon logs an error when it wants an endpoint
that the client can't find, but the error does not
say which endpoint is missing. This change includes
more details in the error message to make debugging
from the horizon logs easier.

Change-Id: I6f0aacd469500238f13a2178a220268d86d31fe5
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

Not a fan of this dhcp rule. We already have a value for dhcp_server in the network object which is supposed to create accept rules. Is there something wrong with that approach?"}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-02-21 20:31:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I will try and explain:
There are rules built that treat return traffic from the DHCP server and the renewal of the leases. The problem is the first request packet that is sent. With traditional nova networking if the dnsmasq is running on the host then the function _add_dnsmasq_accept_rule builds the relevant rule to treat the initial request. To be honest I am not sure how this works if multihost is not enabled and there is a default drop rule.
If Quantum is used the DHCP agent does not create this rule and it could also be running on  different host.
My initial thinking was that if Quantum is enabled then to just add the rule in the init function. I felt like this ay be problematic if someone does not want to the DHCP traffic to be allowed.
What do you suggest?'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2013-02-21 21:02:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I would prefer to not have to check if quantum is enabled. We need to decide whether to create the rule on a parameter of the network objects themselves.'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-02-22 07:59:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-22 08:49:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Enable VM DHCP request to reach DHCP agent

When using the firewall driver IptablesFirewallDriver and the
default INPUT and FORWARD rules are DISCARD then the DHCP
request from the VM is discarded prior to getting to the dnsmasq.

A new rule will be added that enables DHCP requests to pass.

This fixes bug 1131223

Change-Id: I50fad5b63c3c4b22a5d828e3e89353c1ed723332

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-22 21:32:03.000000000', 'message': 'Change nova-dhcpbridge FLAGFILE to a list of files

This patch adds support to linux_net and nova-dhcpbridge for
specifying and conveying multiple dhcpbridge_flagfile values.
The support is implemented as follows:

dhcpbridge_flagfile is now a "MultiStr" configuration file option
allowing the flag files to be defined over multiple configuration files.
The configured files are concatenated into a comma separated string and
assigned to the FLAGFILE environment variable when invoking
nova-dhcpbridge. nova-dhcpbridge splits the value of the environment
variable on the comma an initializes its configuration with the provided
files (the configuration system already supports loading configuration
from multiple files)

Fixes bug 1131932

Change-Id: Ic9cc57b8f7d9356606b9134ef5b63ab07b6099d9

commit_message:
Change nova-dhcpbridge FLAGFILE to a list of files

This patch adds support to linux_net and nova-dhcpbridge for
specifying and conveying multiple dhcpbridge_flagfile values.
The support is implemented as follows:

dhcpbridge_flagfile is now a "MultiStr" configuration file option
allowing the flag files to be defined over multiple configuration files.
The configured files are concatenated into a comma separated string and
assigned to the FLAGFILE environment variable when invoking
nova-dhcpbridge. nova-dhcpbridge splits the value of the environment
variable on the comma an initializes its configuration with the provided
files (the configuration system already supports loading configuration
from multiple files)

Fixes bug 1131932

Change-Id: Ic9cc57b8f7d9356606b9134ef5b63ab07b6099d9

commit_message:
Throw a proper error if the flavor is missing.

I ran into a bug which caused a bt when the flavor is missing on the
targetted system.  This patch makes it throw a proper exception and a
useful error message.

Fixes: bug #1129388
Change-Id: I545fce32732522053e2a4a113a02883a89045910
Signed-off-by: Ian Main <imain@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Allow external calling context to inject values.

To allow non-core projects to use devstack-gate to test their changes without
needing to modify devstack-gate itself, allow injection of values into
PROJECTS and ENABLED_SERVICES from the calling script. Also let the calling
script drop in a localrc fragment and tell devstack gate to not delete it.
That way a jenkins job could set those values and then call an unmodified
devstack-gate.

Change-Id: I12802e3fedd8553e8401dcfaeaa62f8750609b69

[{'created': '2013-02-21 11:37:14.000000000', 'message': 'openstack.common.setup: fails to get version from git

quantum run_tests.py fails because
openstack.common.setup._get_version_from_git fails.  It is because
quantum unit tests run under quantum/tests/unit instead of git root dir.
So the function should check parent dirs for .git.

ERROR: test_network_gateway_update (quantum.tests.unit.nicira.test_networkgw.NetworkGatewayExtensionTestCase)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "quantum/quantum/tests/unit/nicira/test_networkgw.py", line 70, in setUp
    config.parse(args=args)
  File "quantum/quantum/common/config.py", line 99, in parse
    version='%%prog %s' % quantum_version.release_string())
  File "quantum/quantum/openstack/common/version.py", line 63, in release_string
    self.release = self._get_version_from_pkg_resources()
  File "quantum/quantum/openstack/common/version.py", line 56, in _get_version_from_pkg_resources
    return setup.get_version(self.package)
  File "quantum/quantum/openstack/common/setup.py", line 334, in get_version
    raise Exception("Versioning for this project requires either an sdist"
Exception: Versioning for this project requires either an sdist tarball, or access to an upstream git repository.

Change-Id: I2e24c00b5ba8f35381cac081ff72d86ea0d75d19
Fixes: bug #1131162
Signed-off-by: Isaku Yamahata <yamahata@valinux.co.jp>

commit_message:
openstack.common.setup: fails to get version from git

quantum run_tests.py fails because
openstack.common.setup._get_version_from_git fails.  It is because
quantum unit tests run under quantum/tests/unit instead of git root dir.
So the function should check parent dirs for .git.
cinder folks seem to have hit this bug (1125416).

ERROR: test_network_gateway_update (quantum.tests.unit.nicira.test_networkgw.NetworkGatewayExtensionTestCase)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "quantum/quantum/tests/unit/nicira/test_networkgw.py", line 70, in setUp
    config.parse(args=args)
  File "quantum/quantum/common/config.py", line 99, in parse
    version='%%prog %s' % quantum_version.release_string())
  File "quantum/quantum/openstack/common/version.py", line 63, in release_string
    self.release = self._get_version_from_pkg_resources()
  File "quantum/quantum/openstack/common/version.py", line 56, in _get_version_from_pkg_resources
    return setup.get_version(self.package)
  File "quantum/quantum/openstack/common/setup.py", line 334, in get_version
    raise Exception("Versioning for this project requires either an sdist"
Exception: Versioning for this project requires either an sdist tarball, or access to an upstream git repository.

Change-Id: I2e24c00b5ba8f35381cac081ff72d86ea0d75d19
Fixes: bug #1131162 and bug #1125416
Signed-off-by: Isaku Yamahata <yamahata@valinux.co.jp>

commit_message:
Add configuration of instance type creation

Instance types are created in the database migration #133. We should
not seed data into our database in a migration. In the interest of not
breaking existing tools that depend on this behavior, this patch adds
the ability for a deployer to opt out of this auto-creation. Add
'populate_instance_types=False' to your config file before syncing your
nova database to skip the auto-creation of instance types.

Change-Id: I481d47422bf540afa54887684be1f195739e7ba4

commit_message:
Fix broken baremetal migration tests

Change 1c5518ba introduced different user/passwd for the baremetal CI
tests, which did not match the CI systems. Since then, all the baremetal
migration tests have been skipped or failing.

This patch sets the user/passwd back to 'openstack_citest'.

Change-Id: I88508d83d6e9e63f20c26704ec6b455c48a33e8f

subject: Make auth url extensible to other mechanisms
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-14 05:34:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/21943/1/check/gate-noop/496 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-02-14 05:36:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The idea is that, in the future, we will want to support other forms.  X509 comes to mind first and foremost, but SAML,etc can be done this way as well.'}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2013-02-14 08:14:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Can this be done as query string or header instead? Something like

/auth?type=x509

If type is absent, it defaults to token. Otherwise, I can't see how we can get away with supporting other credentials without having to define new APIs anyway.

Besides, having middleware be able to handle all the different types of credentials won't be that fun. :)"}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-02-14 16:50:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This is already addressed by the list of authentication methods in the request body, along with each authentication method having its own namespace in the request body. This change also breaks the semantics of providing multiple authentication methods to achieve multifactor within a single request."}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2013-02-14 17:15:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I don't think this is about authentication methods. It is about what the result of a successful authentication. A token? An X.509 certificate? A Kerberos ticket? or something else?

I think Adam's intention is to abstract credential in the future. All I am saying is this will significant increase the complexity of doing business with Keystone. I am not saying its a bad thing. Just trade-offs we need to consider."}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-02-14 18:12:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Is it not already abstracted? The API treats the token in the response header as an opaque value, which could be anything. Making that value transparent is an implementation detail today, and I don't see why it should be an API-user concern at all."}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2013-02-14 20:14:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

How do we intend to support different types at the same time? Right now token is either a UUID or CMS blob. We can't support both at the same time. If I understand Adam correctly, he wants to be able to support all types of credentials at the same time.

That right Adam or this is for something else?"}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-02-15 03:35:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Usually, you would not specify the mime type to retrieve a certificate.  You want to be able to provide a link to a cert and the browser is capable of importing it, etc.  I don't think having it as an additional parameter will work.  This is not a "content type accepted" question so much as "content type requested"  where the browser should be able to get, potentially, a human readable form of the data....all this is presupposing we will be moving toward HATEOAS and being able to directly expose as subset of Keystone resources direct to browser.  I can be swayed on this if you can point to a resource that shows how it should be done with a single URL.'}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2013-02-15 21:13:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

+1 for HATEOAS'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-02-18 15:56:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I guess I'm stumbling on the problem with using the Accept request header. We already require proper "application/json" or "application/xml" request headers, so the idea of requiring "Accept: application/json" but "oh actually for this URL give me a different type of response" doesn't make any sense.

  14.1: Accept
  The Accept request-header field can be used to specify certain media types
  which are acceptable for the response. Accept headers can be used to indicate
  that the request is specifically limited to a small set of desired types...

  10.4.7: 406 Not Acceptable
  The resource identified by the request is only capable of generating response
  entities which have content characteristics not acceptable according to the
  accept headers sent in the request.

Although, I'm still not clear if you intend to return JSON with an attribute containing a blob (e.g. cert), or returning something else instead of JSON?'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-02-18 17:13:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

This will require significant reworking.'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-02-18 17:14:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Restored

Abandoned the wrong change.  Restored.  I stand by this being essential for future interop.  AuthN/AuthZ formats are going to be much more than an opaque blob.  We need to be able to vary content as well as format.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-02-19 18:48:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

"what I want to do is to replace tokens with X509" -ayoung

ayoung wants to totally, completely rip out and replace all aspects of tokens across openstack... to achieve that, i agree that this change is appropriate'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-02-25 20:51:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-25 20:51:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/21943/2/check/gate-noop/577 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-02-25 20:51:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

This is a by hand rebase.'}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2013-02-25 21:02:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-25 21:02:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

Starting gate jobs.

We booted a server just for a single test case.

The server actions fixture have a logic for:
* Dealing with server dies between test cases.
* Useing a single server when it is possible (Normally it is)

+ Negativ tests using the assertRaises

Change-Id: Ifa586febe9f336fcebada5ec66cbc3d81fdd51a0
'}]
commit_message:
Move the console tests to the other server actions tests

We booted a server just for a single test case.

The server actions fixture have a logic for:
* Dealing with server dies between test cases.
* Useing a single server when it is possible (Normally it is)

+ Negativ tests using the assertRaises

Change-Id: Ifa586febe9f336fcebada5ec66cbc3d81fdd51a0

(18 inline comments)

The wording suggests that trusts represent impersonation along with delegation...?

I think trusts are a great avenue for implementing impersonation, but impersonation MUST be an additional opt-in on behalf of the trustor. Trusting another user should NOT imply that they can impersonate me as well, unless I explicitly allow it, e.g.

Details of the trust Programmtic interface

Change-Id: I8215cbf39a8aba826419e89d3f10aa354dbf9266
'}, {'created': '2013-02-19 18:14:24.000000000', 'message': "Trust API

A trust represents one user's (the 'trustor') authorization to
delegate roles to second user (the 'trustee') at a point in the
future.  The trust contains the constraints on the delegation of
attributes that can then be used to create tokens.
Once the trustor has created a trust, the trustee can pass the trust's
`id` attribute along with a `create token` request to the identity
server.

A token requested with a trust id (a `trust token`) will specify the
trustor as the user_id instead of the trustee.
An issued  trust-token can then be used by the trustee to perform
operations on behalf of the trustor.

Change-Id: I8215cbf39a8aba826419e89d3f10aa354dbf9266
"}, {'created': '2013-02-19 18:23:28.000000000', 'message': "Trust API

A trust represents one user's (the 'trustor') authorization to
delegate roles to second user (the 'trustee') at a point in the
future.  The trust contains the constraints on the delegation of
attributes that can then be used to create tokens.
Once the trustor has created a trust, the trustee can pass the trust's
`id` attribute along with a `create token` request to the identity

A token requested with a trust id (a `trust token`) will specify the
trustor as the user_id instead of the trustee.
An issued  trust-token can then be used by the trustee to perform
operations on behalf of the trustor.

Change-Id: I8215cbf39a8aba826419e89d3f10aa354dbf9266
"}, {'created': '2013-02-25 03:12:06.000000000', 'message': "Trust API

A trust represents one user's (the 'trustor') authorization to
delegate roles to second user (the 'trustee') at a point in the
future.  The trust contains the constraints on the delegation of
attributes that can then be used to create tokens.
Once the trustor has created a trust, the trustee can pass the trust's
`id` attribute along with a `create token` request to the identity
server.

A token requested with a trust id (a `trust token`) will specify the
trustor as the user_id instead of the trustee.
An issued  trust-token can then be used by the trustee to perform
operations on behalf of the trustor.

Change-Id: I8215cbf39a8aba826419e89d3f10aa354dbf9266
"}, {'created': '2013-02-25 14:20:39.000000000', 'message': "Trust API

commit_message:
Trusts API (bp trusts)

Credit mostly due to ayoung, based on his work in:

  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/22063/

This patch is simply an evolution of the above.

Trusts introduce delegated authorization and impersonation capabilities
into the v3 API.

Change-Id: I8215cbf39a8aba826419e89d3f10aa354dbf9266

use a temp file instead).  However, if it is left that way, subsequent

commit_message:
Ensure keystone unittests do not leave CONF.policyfile in bad state

A few of the tests overwrite the name of the policy file (so they can
use a temp file instead).  However, if it is left that way, subsequent
tests that rely on it may fail.

A separate patch will look at doing a more comprehensive reset in the
setup of test_v3 - ensuring we always start from a completely clean
slate for all confirguration parameters.

Fixes Bug #1131819

Change-Id: Ibe5ee12f44310de00b12ddd405c83f59b2d840b7

'}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2013-01-24 13:52:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2013-01-28 15:05:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (3 inline comments)

This looks a little bit dangerous, because the names of the functions imply that they are idempotent but, in fact, ensure_str() is not for any encoding != UTF-8 because it assumes that byte strings it is passed are encoded in UTF-8.

I would suggest instead decoding them from ASCII - that way it still works for converting string literals in the code (assuming few people are crazy enough to put escaped UTF-8 sequences in a string literal), but will fail slightly more easily in the event that it is used inappropriately (to re-encode an already-encoded byte string).'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-01-28 17:22:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Where are these new functions meant to be used? They look like the sort of thing that might end up being placed in the middle of a library where the input type isn't known, instead of enforcing type conversion at a boundary where we know what we're receiving or emitting."}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-01-28 17:36:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-28 17:40:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/20393/4/check/gate-oslo-incubator-docs/563 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/20393/4/check/gate-oslo-incubator-pep8/748 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/20393/4/check/gate-oslo-incubator-pyflakes/499 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/20393/4/check/gate-oslo-incubator-python26/748 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/20393/4/check/gate-oslo-incubator-python27/748 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-01-28 17:40:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Right now, they're meant to be used in nova's and glance's clients in order to support non-ASCII characters, which is currently an issue for both of them (see bugs in the commit message).

The new review implements `incoming` which represents the incoming text encoding. If None, python's default will be used."}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-01-28 22:18:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-28 22:29:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

- http://logs.openstack.org/20393/5/check/gate-oslo-incubator-python27/757 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-01-29 14:32:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Flavio - could you propose a WIP fix for glanceclient or novaclient that shows how this will be used?

I think that will help people review this patch

It smells like a similar problem to Icc2aabe9c0c521732003f7013438630ebc8d2238 and 931667'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-01-29 14:32:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

commit_message:
Decode / Encode string utils for openstack

Currently some clients lack of non-ASCII characters support. This patch
introduces 2 functions (strutils.py) that will help clients and servers
to "safely" encode and decode strings.

About the ensure_(str|unicode) functions:

    They both try to use first the encoding used in stdin (or python's
    default encoding if that's None) and fallback to utf-8 if those
    encodings fail to decode a given text.

    Neither of them will try to encode / decode non-basestring objects
    and will raise a TypeError if one is passed.

Use case:

This is currently being used in glanceclient. I5c3ea93a716edfe284d19f6291d4e36028f91eb2

Needed For:
    * Bug 1061156
    * Bug 1130572

Change-Id: I78960dfdb6159fd600a6f5e5551ab5d5a3366ab5

commit_message:
Updates for current Grenade configuration

* Adds new required variables for grenade configuration
* Work around permissions issues before changing to stack user
* Run grenade out of new/grenade

Change-Id: Ie9af1ed6eb25ca118cf715d7503b9539751b496e

commit_message:
Pin jsonschema version below 1.0.0.

The latest jsonschema version breaks the unit tests. This commit pins
the version to be less than the latest release.

Fixes bug 1132840

Change-Id: Ib4db4782f995cee179445ca11d2b6a7f13a6b457

commit_message:
Replace tearDown with addCleanup.

testtools.addCleanup is more reliable than tearDown methods, as it
builds a stack of things that need to be cleaned up and ensures
that each run, even if there was a problem with one of the other
cleanups. It also allows for defining the cleanup with the
fixture.

Change-Id: I66c3498113b0d2e3185822e90fcca4cba898cbe3

commit_message:
Update flakes.py to match 0.6.1.

pyflakes 0.6.1 changes a module path - but we want to use it, because it
finally groks attributes properly.

commit_message:
Support qpid unit tests.

The qpid unit tests have never been run by default because qpid is not
on pypi.  I filed a bug asking the qpid project to support it:

    https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/QPID-4539

Until that happens, I uploaded a package to pypi myself.

    https://pypi.python.org/pypi/qpid-python

Fix bug 1061055.

Change-Id: I2d52ff383b6393f34e94c25f959dccda5a7571de

[{'created': '2013-02-22 23:39:49.000000000', 'message': "Readd run_tests.sh --debug option.

Testr doesn't directly support running tests with pdb so the --debug
options was pulled from run_tests.sh during the testr switch. Add the
flag back into run_tests.sh and have it run tests with testtools.run
which allows users to import pdb in tests then run them without
interference from testr.

Example usage:
  # First edit test file to import pdb.
  run_tests.sh -d path.to.test

If the test is not given on the command line all tests will be run.

Change-Id: I4afca9ca997ccb6c575b714b778a9db8306c7891
"}, {'created': '2013-02-22 23:51:51.000000000', 'message': "Readd run_tests.sh --debug option.

commit_message:
Readd run_tests.sh --debug option.

Testr doesn't directly support running tests with pdb so the --debug
option was pulled from run_tests.sh during the testr switch. Add the
flag back into run_tests.sh and have it run tests with testtools.run
which allows users to import pdb in tests then run them without
interference from testr.

Example usage:
  # First edit test file to import pdb.
  run_tests.sh -d path.to.test

If the test is not given on the command line all tests will be run.

Change-Id: I4afca9ca997ccb6c575b714b778a9db8306c7891

commit_message:
latest jsonschema (1.0) breaks glance

Version 1.0 introduced some backward incompatible changes. This patch
forces jsonschema<=0.8 in the pip requirement.

Fixes bug 1132839

Change-Id: I18120cc78d667e92d7c0bebeb860515b0188c42d

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-23 16:04:12.000000000', 'message': 'Clean unused kernels and ramdisks from image cache

Fixes bug #1132138

Only unused disk images are currently cleaned up by the image cache
manager but it seems logical to clean up unused kernels and ramdisks
too.

Achieve that by writing kernels and ramdisks to disk using the sha1
sum of their ID as the filename. This is the same scheme as used for
disk image filenames and causes the image cache manager to consider
them for cleanup. We also make the cache manager take note of in use
kernels and ramdisks when iterating over the list of instances.

A nasty upgrade concern is that if we immediately switch to writing
kernels to disk using this scheme then, where shared storage is used,
we can have older image cache managers on remote compute nodes cleaning
up kernels because they appear unused. To mitigate that, turn off this
behaviour by default and allow it to be enabled using a new config
option. This option will be removed in future and the behaviour enabled
by default.

DocImpact: new remove_unused_kernels option

Change-Id: I56bba9fa6596601104498e262c2e657f0eae2fa0
'}, {'created': '2013-02-23 16:06:03.000000000', 'message': 'Clean unused kernels and ramdisks from image cache

commit_message:
Clean unused kernels and ramdisks from image cache

Fixes bug #1132138

Only unused disk images are currently cleaned up by the image cache
manager but it seems logical to clean up unused kernels and ramdisks
too.

Achieve that by writing kernels and ramdisks to disk using the sha1
sum of their ID as the filename. This is the same scheme as used for
disk image filenames and causes the image cache manager to consider
them for cleanup. We also make the cache manager take note of in use
kernels and ramdisks when iterating over the list of instances.

A nasty upgrade concern is that if we immediately switch to writing
kernels to disk using this scheme then, where shared storage is used,
we can have older image cache managers on remote compute nodes cleaning
up kernels because they appear unused. To mitigate that, turn off this
behaviour by default and allow it to be enabled using a new config
option. This option will be removed in future and the behaviour enabled
by default.

DocImpact: new remove_unused_kernels option

Change-Id: I56bba9fa6596601104498e262c2e657f0eae2fa0

commit_message:
Clean up sqlalchemy exception code

Moves DB exceptions that can be shared between DB implementations into
their own module.

Adds DBDeadlock() exception wrapping.  Nova has its own code for
determining Deadlock and it's better to consolidate it with
DBDuplicateKey checking.

Change-Id: I108bd0da2a14d62e460a997b1472f0b65bfc9b95

Remove compat cfg wrapper

This wrapper was there to allow oslo-config changes through the gate

Also update to 2013.1b4.

Add shell.py so we can do v2 shell commands

fixes bug #1132633
Signed-off-by: Angus Salkeld <asalkeld@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Allow prettytable 0.7.0 or newer as well.

Seems to work just fine. Matching change also
submitted for glanceclient so that both can
be installed in parallel.

Change-Id: Ica2ce1999a2882ddc17e95398cad8b396fe63bc0

'aliveness' by nova- services

Change-Id: I2a0d14da08a0d9143bb15db4b292b8ef2db688fb

commit_message:
Add servicegroup_driver config option

fixes bug 1084500

Grizzly introduced the ServiceGroup APIs in nova - a set of abstract
internal APIs with pluggable backend to deal with the reporting of
'aliveness' by nova- services

Change-Id: I2a0d14da08a0d9143bb15db4b292b8ef2db688fb

commit_message:
Pin pyzmq to avoid v13 release breakage.

I don't know why we think that python packages can be trusted to keep an API.

Change-Id: I21aa1e8bfa7f10ebb0296dc94ec24900a4af3797

'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-02-12 01:49:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Does tempest touch the EC2 API?  IIRC, Dan Prince was still running these tests to at least exercise EC2.  Dan?'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-02-12 01:56:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

yes, the boto tests do - https://github.com/openstack/tempest/tree/master/tempest/tests/boto'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-02-12 01:57:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Russell,

I still run these... have been for years now. If these need to go elsewhere they can. What is the urgency?'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-02-12 02:00:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

sdague: I don't think the tests in Tempest exactly match these. If we were to *copy* these into Tempest... then I could probably run them."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-02-12 02:08:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

if there is a gap here, let's get it addressed, but whole sale copy really shouldn't happen as a lot of the function is over there already. I put attila on the review as he's the redhat team member that's been contributing to tempest, who did the boto work, so can hopefully speak to how these compare."}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2013-02-12 03:04:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

No _urgency_ - I was just starting through the task of porting all of the testing changes we did to nova over to cinder, and it struck me that we had the smoketests dir still sitting there - and given the existence of temptest, we should probably just go ahead and do what needs done to get rid of it...'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-02-12 03:09:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not merge

From my prospective Tempest is more along the lines of full coverage where as smoke tests will always be meant to run fast (what I want).

Call me old school... but these tests have served me well over the years. I'm happy to move them elsewhere though if Nova devs find their existence annoying."}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2013-02-12 04:30:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I don't want to take away useful things! There's a few things though:

- They have no documentation
- They now use a whole different toolchain than the rest of the tests

But if they make you happy - more power to them. I'd love to know how to run them - and if I knew how, I'd love to get them integrated so that other people could, too..."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-02-12 11:09:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: No score

There is no urgency here, but I do think we should remove them in Havana. The community around testing has migrated to Tempest, and its better to get more voices and code there to make that suitable for everyone's needs than split the effort and have a set of tests hanging out here."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-02-12 14:06:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

sdague: Perhaps you have overstating things a bit. I'm not sure the existence of these tests really takes away from Tempest. If you look at the changelog I think you'll find very little has changed in these tests over the past year. Like I said before these have served me well (I like tests suites that don't change). I also like test suites that run fairly quickly. The Nova Smoke Tests do both of those for me.

Also, while I do appreciate the additions we've made in Tempest I don't necessarily subscribe to the "one to rule them all" test suite mindset. Also, I use vi. To write Ruby even.'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-02-17 13:55:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

The fact that they run quickly, and continue to work with no maintainer, isn't really an argument for their efficacy. Do we have instances where these tests have managed to flag a bug that weren't in tempest? (especially since we got postgresql into ci)

The eyeballs that are spending their time thinking about ways to optimize testing, ways to optimize ci, and the ways to measure how good our testing is, are all over in the qa team focused on tempest. The argument that we shouldn't collaborate over there seems odd to me. If there is a reason that tempest isn't meeting the needs of a consumer, we should figure out how to go after that.

I think this is even more true that the smoketests don't belong in the nova tree, as they *only* test the EC2 API, and not the OpenStack API.

I get that there is going to be a cost to switching SmokeStack over, but I really feel like the existence of the smoketests is technical debt. Duplicating an effort in another place and splitting our efforts in creating validation for OpenStack. Anyway, we can take this to the list post release, or at summit. But I think removing this directory in havana would be a good thing."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-02-25 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-02-25 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

[{'created': '2013-02-01 05:07:06.000000000', 'message': 'Get updated vol status in volume.api.reserve.

A race condtion was discovered where a nova volume attach
could easily be performed twice for the same volume.  Although
the cinder attach update would fail, this occured after the BDM
updates were made and in essence the attach to the compute instance
had already been issued.

This change simply forces a get from the DB of the volume-ref in the
reserve call and checks if an attach is already in progress.

Fixes bug: 1096983

Change-Id: Ie0e4156d691ee92b6981078ef0ba62f8c4cdf0c8
(cherry picked from commit 2c84413c74e6481abe4af716ea12d8c75b405c25)

commit_message:
Get updated vol status in volume.api.reserve.

A race condtion was discovered where a nova volume attach
could easily be performed twice for the same volume.  Although
the cinder attach update would fail, this occured after the BDM
updates were made and in essence the attach to the compute instance
had already been issued.

This change simply forces a get from the DB of the volume-ref in the
reserve call and checks if an attach is already in progress.

Fixes bug: 1096983

Change-Id: Ie0e4156d691ee92b6981078ef0ba62f8c4cdf0c8
(cherry picked from commit 2c84413c74e6481abe4af716ea12d8c75b405c25)

commit_message:
LinuxBridge: set port status as 'DOWN' on creation

When a port is created the initial status will be 'DOWN'. The agent
in turn will update the plugin of the actual port status.

Fixes bug 1099065

Change-Id: I66b51501304f7cb3f0157a4adaec4b82c62b30a3

commit_message:
Changes return type in powervm macs_for_instance from set to list

Fixes bug 1131035

Qpid does not have encoding for set type, spawn flow is broken
when qpid is used as amqp provider.

Change-Id: I4efa9e42cc3a5c471d5767ea4036678478b35003

commit_message:
XenAPINFS: Fix Volume always uploaded as vhd/ovf

Fixes bug 1131291

copy_volume_to_image was always using the glance plugin to do the
upload, and was ignoring the users request. Thus the image was always
uploaded as vhd/ovf. This patch is using the image utils to fix the
generic case.

Change-Id: If12c3d175b3d4437305ac4d2f954a2a42ee3a3c1

commit_message:
Add tests for server metadata

* Raise exception while passing too many metadata items during
set server metadata
* Raise exception while passing too many metadata items during
update server metadata
* Passing an empty body during update server metadata preserves
original metadata items
* Make exception asserts consistent in all test cases

Partially implements bp missing-tempest-tests

Change-Id: I66d5102ddda10072943c454578eb445a3a480b1c

subject: Protect AccessKey deletion from failing
messages:
[{'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2013-02-22 09:22:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Shouldn't the AccessKey resource always depend on the User resource, so User should be deleted after the AccessKey, so this lookup should never fail? :confused:

E.g in the HA template, we have a Ref to CfnUser in WebServerKeys, so I'd expect the CfnUser to get deleted after WebServerKeys, if it's not then we probably have a bug"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-22 09:22:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

commit_message:
Protect AccessKey deletion from failing

The deletion calls _get_user() that calls FnGetRefId for each
resource. But since this is the delete most resources have been
deleted.

bug #1131534

Change-Id: I08ffd27d1d05214b1a8cf86744e7d4f91d7e1558

commit_message:
Remove compat cfg wrapper

This wrapper was there to allow oslo-config changes through the gate
while keystoneclient hadn't been updated.

Change-Id: I3d48673af58ae379e8e4d2c7fb4b4d81f3ed67dd

commit_message:
Make quantumclient optional again

Don't crash if quantumclient is not available; just don't register the
resource types that require it.

Change-Id: I9dacc5397327ef7ec784f808227582ee9bd037df
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
allow run_tests.sh to report why it failed

the set -e was suppressing all the echo information about why
run_tests.sh was failing, which makes it quite hard to figure out
what is going on.

Change-Id: Ie210ee5b5e9ff0028a89da520580db7cd1d9f03a

commit_message:
Remove external_id and security group proxy code

This code is no longer needed since nova can now proxy these calls to
quantum directly.

Fixes bug 1130927

Change-Id: I62f8d7d4161f8a1308ae80029effaa46b6d661a3

commit_message:
Added contentwidth attibute to images for pdf builds

contentwidth="6in" was added (or modified from scale="60") to imagedata elements
in the following files:
  doc/src/docbkx/common/dashboard_customizing.xml
  doc/src/docbkx/common/getstart.xml
  doc/src/docbkx/common/trusted-compute-pools.xml
  doc/src/docbkx/common/vmware.xml
  doc/src/docbkx/openstack-compute-admin/computeconfigure.xml
  doc/src/docbkx/openstack-compute-admin/computevolumes.xml
This makes big images fit in correctly in pdf builds.

Change-Id: I0d3a410d043be93a94d04842603428368e4d78ca

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-23 20:30:38.000000000', 'message': "Add fallocate_reserve option to docs

fixes bug 1095507

Grizzly's swift introduced fallocate_reserve=0 - the
number of bytes to reserve on the disk. This value can be used
to more gracefully handle out-of-disk space errors.

commit_message:
Add fallocate_reserve option to docs

fixes bug 1095507

Grizzly's swift introduced fallocate_reserve=0 - the
number of bytes to reserve on the disk. This value can be used
to more gracefully handle out-of-disk space errors.

The patch adds the option to account/object/container conf tables

Change-Id: If5ff2ddb8f931d1bc4d7a3b28a801fa6e903d33d

subject: Disable libvirt base file cleanup by default
messages:
[{'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-02-15 16:33:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

When this kind of option is disabled by default it gets little-to-no real world testing, and as a result the code will bit-rot over time, becoming more & more buggy. This would make it impractical for anyone to ever enable it. Either this should remain enabled by default so that the code gets regularly execised ensuring bugs can be identified & fixed, or the cleanup code removed entirely. Disabling by default is not desirable from an ongoing maintenance POV."}, {'account_id': 6859, 'date': '2013-02-15 16:38:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

From a development point of view, I understand where you are coming from. However, from an operational point of view, these types of settings are extremely dangerous. In my very humble opinion, the reason no feedback is given for features like this is because they're too dangerous to run in a stable environment."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-15 18:19:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

'}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2013-02-16 05:59:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not merge

This code was added because the reality is that deployers (especially small ones) don't monitor their logs for these messages and will eventually run out of disk on their compute nodes. I would consider disabling this option to be dangerous."}, {'account_id': 6859, 'date': '2013-02-16 06:38:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

You're correct - running out of disk space is not a good situation to be in, but the core issue is that OpenStack making a default choice on behalf of the operator to permanently remove data without an explicit action being taken.

You're also correct that most operators do not read the OpenStack log files. But most operators do monitor disk usage. It's more probable that they would realize they're running out of disk space (or have already ran out) quicker than trying to understand why data has disappeared from their environment.

In the event of running out of disk space, at least the data is still available. The operator then has the ability to choose whether they want to clean images up, move them up to another location, or expand the disk where _base is located. Having this feature enabled by default is making a choice on behalf of the operator. Choices that deal with permanently removing data is something to not take lightly.

I understand that I'm at the losing end of a debate. I'd like to at least request that features like this are more visible to the average operator. Just like most operators don't read log files, most won't read the nova.conf reference to learn that features like this exist. Please try to put yourself in a position where you are using a new product and all of the sudden you find yourself missing data."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-02-24 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-02-24 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-15 16:13:55.000000000', 'message': 'Disable libvirt base file cleanup by default

Both as a systems administrator responsible for OpenStack environments
and as someone who was bit by this feature being enabled, I feel that
remove_unused_base_images should be False as default. Having a "delete"
setting turned on by default can be very dangerous. No matter how many
precautions are taken, some scenarios will still slip by. In my opinion,
it is a better operational problem to have someone report an abundance of
unused images that they can opt-in to delete rather than having a user
report images that have been deleted without them understanding why and
not being able to restore them.

bug 1126375

Change-Id: Idb0b4a1fb78a68d5220ceaa9c939a32524bfac3a
'}]
commit_message:
Disable libvirt base file cleanup by default

Both as a systems administrator responsible for OpenStack environments
and as someone who was bit by this feature being enabled, I feel that
remove_unused_base_images should be False as default. Having a "delete"
setting turned on by default can be very dangerous. No matter how many
precautions are taken, some scenarios will still slip by. In my opinion,
it is a better operational problem to have someone report an abundance of
unused images that they can opt-in to delete rather than having a user
report images that have been deleted without them understanding why and
not being able to restore them.

bug 1126375

Change-Id: Idb0b4a1fb78a68d5220ceaa9c939a32524bfac3a

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-13 10:24:23.000000000', 'message': "Fix load balancer

The haproxy service wasn't being configured properly which resulted in
load balancer not working.

This was due to multiple causes:

* load balancer didn't use cfn-credentials
* cfn-hup was asking for the metadata of the nested stack and resource
(which isn't accessible from the Heat API)
* `systemctl reload haproxy.service` in hooks.conf always resulted in
a stopped service -- even with seemingly correct haproxy config file
* the policy check wasn't allowing access to nested stacks' metadata via
the describe_stack_resource API
* cfn-hup doesn't trigger events in the same order as they appear in the
hooks.conf file (which resulted in haproxy being restarted before its
configuration was updated)

The fixes here make the autoscaling template working again but the fix
is not complete. The changes here don't rely on cfntools update.

The following ought to be looked into separately:

* cfn-hup should trigger the events in the order they're written
* cfn-hup currently triggers the post.update events every time it's
called -- even when the metadata didn't change.
* related to that and the `systemctl reload` issue, haproxy gets
restarted every minute.

Change-Id: I980a6da56db2eb06916a137e7e9412ad54737ba0
Signed-off-by: Tomas Sedovic <tomas@sedovic.cz>
"}]
commit_message:
Fix load balancer

The haproxy service wasn't being configured properly which resulted in
load balancer not working.

This was due to multiple causes:

* load balancer didn't use cfn-credentials
* cfn-hup was asking for the metadata of the nested stack and resource
(which isn't accessible from the Heat API)
* `systemctl reload haproxy.service` in hooks.conf always resulted in
a stopped service -- even with seemingly correct haproxy config file
* the policy check wasn't allowing access to nested stacks' metadata via
the describe_stack_resource API
* cfn-hup doesn't trigger events in the same order as they appear in the
hooks.conf file (which resulted in haproxy being restarted before its
configuration was updated)

The fixes here make the autoscaling template working again but the fix
is not complete. The changes here don't rely on cfntools update.

The following ought to be looked into separately:

* cfn-hup should trigger the events in the order they're written
* cfn-hup currently triggers the post.update events every time it's
called -- even when the metadata didn't change.
* related to that and the `systemctl reload` issue, haproxy gets
restarted every minute.

Change-Id: I980a6da56db2eb06916a137e7e9412ad54737ba0
Signed-off-by: Tomas Sedovic <tomas@sedovic.cz>

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-01-29 12:59:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hmm, the issue here appears to be that we've read and processed a message but haven't yet acked it

We basically need to keep a queue of messages which we have not yet acked and keep trying to send the ack until we succeed?

I guess that's more or less what your patch is doing?"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-01-29 13:02:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(3 inline comments)

Hmm, I don't like the idea of relying on the fact that we'll re-read an unacked message

If we know the ack was never sent, why not just re-send it rather than waiting until we re-read the original message?"}, {'account_id': 6681, 'date': '2013-01-29 15:31:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (3 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 6539, 'date': '2013-01-29 23:04:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I am going to comment on the code separately, but help out Kei by addressing some of Mark's comments.  One of the problems with HA and a clustered and mirrored RabbitMQ is failover isn't perfect.  It is documented on the in the RabbitMQ documentation.  Here is a link: http://www.rabbitmq.com/ha.html
Search for acknowledgement.  What Kei is addressing here is the duplicate resend of the same message mentioned in the link.  So the message has already been acked.  It just needs to be acked a a second time and thrown away.  Kei's suggestion for a fix is simple and efficient, but does need some rework.  I'll address in a separate review comment."}, {'account_id': 6539, 'date': '2013-01-29 23:59:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(8 inline comments)

Mainly because I would like to see the existing _msg_id be used, but I could be convinced otherwise, since the _msg_id is added by another module amqp.py.  I suppose another option would be to add a get_msg_id(msg) to the amqp.py module.  Either way, I don't think another message ID should be or needs to be added to the message."}, {'account_id': 6681, 'date': '2013-01-30 02:39:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1075, 'date': '2013-01-30 02:52:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hello reviewers,
   
Thanks for your comment! I appreciate it.
   
> Raymond,
   
Thanks for your comment and help me addressing on this issue. Before I'm going to rework to this patch, let me explain why I added to another msg_id.
   
I was thinking that using msg_id is better, but in current implementation, msg_id is used to recognize whether return value is necessary or not. i.e., msg_id is not added to cast message.

To recognize the duplicate resend of the same message, id is necessary to any message. Correct me if I misunderstand...

P.S. after I am writing this messages, I found Brent left a same comment. I agree with him.."}, {'account_id': 6539, 'date': '2013-01-30 03:26:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: No score

(1 inline comment)

Few comments ...

1) How likely is it that anyone would every change the value for this new configuration option?  Is this something we can just define as a constant in the file and skip the configuration option?  I just like to avoid new options unless really necessary.

2) I'd like to see this updated to apply the same fix to impl_qpid, as well.  It works the same way as impl_kombu.  It could either be a part of this patch, or if someone wants to volunteer to follow up with another patch, that's fine with me, too.

Perhaps this could be done in rpc.amqp (the common layer between the two modules) ?

3) Perhaps dup_check_id could be renamed to something like unique_id?  The idea would be to name it after what it is, as opposed to what it is currently used for, since it could be used for something else in the future."}, {'account_id': 6539, 'date': '2013-02-02 17:27:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: No score

The advantage of Russell's idea of making the change in amqp.py is the existing msg_id can be used for RPC calls (and extended to other types of RPCs).  The disadvantage is adding unnecessary checking to implementations that don't need it.  I originally suggested not checking for HA in impl_kombu.py because I felt RabbitMQ would primary be used in an HA environment.  I suppose we could use that same argument to say that RabbitMQ will be more common than Qpid, so let Qpid pay the cost too.  Or perhaps duplicate messages are possible in Qpid too.  If we do this, then I think there should be a clear comment in the code that states the reason for the checking is for RabbitMQ with HA mirroring where duplicate messages can occur."}, {'account_id': 6539, 'date': '2013-02-03 16:53:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Sorry, Kei for having to make so many changes, but now I'm leaning very much toward putting the changes in amqp.py.  And if someone feels that we shouldn't do this for Qpid or some other future RPC implementation, we could provide a method in amqp.py for disabling duplicate message checking.  I don't recommend adding such a method and all the checking for it now.  It's just knowing how how to handle a future implementation that doesn't want duplicate message checking is enough, I think.

The biggest advantage to having the change in amqp.py is the ability to use the existing msg_id in the message for RPC calls.  I think that is huge.  We would just now have msg_id on the other types of RPCs as well.

As far as having a cache size option or not, I have no preference."}, {'account_id': 6539, 'date': '2013-02-03 17:20:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Hmph, It is never easy.  I couldn't remember how RPC handles replies for calls versus not sending replies for casts.  In looking at the amqp.py ProxyCallback class and the RpcContext reply() method, I am led to believe the need to send a reply is based upon having received a msg_id in the message.  So, simply adding msg_id to casts will not work and will in fact break backward compatibility.

One possible solution would be to use msg_id for duplicate checking on RPC calls and add a msg_id_nc or some other key for duplicate message checking for RPCs other than call."}, {'account_id': 1075, 'date': '2013-02-04 01:23:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Raymond, let me make sure. I am little bit confusing..

Your opinion is that this patch should be abandoned for now, because this bug should be fixed at amqp.py and we don't know this fix is needed for qpid. correct?
Or your opinion is that this patch should make changes to amqp.py, not impl_kombu?
I just want to make clear what the next step is..."}, {'account_id': 6539, 'date': '2013-02-04 18:46:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Kei, thank you for your patience.  I did some research and found that the duplicate message problem can occur in a HA failover situation for Qpid as well, just as Russell said.  Therefore, there are several good reasons for doing the patch in amqp.py instead of impl_kombu.py.  It is more complicated in amqp.py and I will provide you with some help with that.  

Here are the places you will have to make a change. I am leaving off RPC call because it already adds a msg_id and I want to reuse it.

Sending messages:

From the initiator of the RPC side, the non-call RPCs will need to add a message id by some other name than _msg_id, since _msg_id in the message indicates a repy is needed.  I suggests _msg_id_nc for non-call.  It needs to be added to these methods:  cast, fanout_cast, cast-to_server, fanout_cast_to_server, notify.

The receiver of the RPC will need to remove the msg_id and do duplicate checking.  It will have to handle receiving both a _msg_id and a _msg_id_nc.  This would be done in ProxyCallback.__call__().  I recommend logging an info message and simply doing a "raise" if there is a duplicate.  Even better, you could define a duplicate message exception and raise it.  It looks like impl_qpid.py would handle it fine, since it's acknowledge happens in a finally clause.  You would need to modify impl_kombu.py to do the same.

It wouldn't hurt to add the new _msg_id_nc to the context in unpack_context, but someone else might have a different opinion.

On the sending side of the response, you would need to add the msg_id back into the reply.  This would be done in msg_reply() just before the direct_send().

On the receiving of the reply, you would want again to check for duplicate messages, log an info message and raise an exception if there was a duplicate.  This would be in MulticallWaiter.__call__().

Hope this helps.'}, {'account_id': 1075, 'date': '2013-02-05 02:30:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Raymond, thanks for explanation! things are clear now. I will submit updated patchset soon..'}, {'account_id': 1075, 'date': '2013-02-08 11:26:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-08 11:31:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-02-08 19:23:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Ray: we will need a unique message identifier for each message for the trusted messaging blueprint. It is true that this cannot be the msg_id, because the msg_id is really a reply identifier and is not necessarily unique per message.

For trusted messaging, the idea there is much the same as with this patch, to prevent replays. (although there, the fear is that replays would be intentional, rather than a quirk of the messaging bus)'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-02-09 03:31:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

I suppose my previous message could use some clarification.

I believe this should be done as a wrapper around, or inside of, serialize_msg and deserialize_msg. Specifically, the message  (and not necessarily "msg_id") should be added and checked as part of the envelope.

My problems with this patch are as follows:
* Having msg_id and msg_id_nc adds a bit of complexity that seems unwarranted. It is also a bit confusing. One key/value can satisfy this requirement, although it may have to be in parallel to msg_id.
* This is Rabbit/Qpid specific, whereas it can be made to work with ZeroMQ without duplication of effort. Don't repeat yourself, etc.
* Duplicate message ids should not be checked, we should check for duplicate message hashes.
* Replay detection should happen earlier, before the heavy operation of message deserialization (or signature verification, once added)
* We need this functionality for trusted messaging to prevent replays. Since trusted messaging is intended to be supported for all rpc mechanisms, it would be ideal that our replay detection is as well.

My idea is to use a nonce in each message, which is effectively an identifier. The nonce key/val would be added to the envelope and serialized along with the user-specified message, but not *in* the user-specified message. The receiver would check for previously seen message hashes, NOT for duplicate message identifiers/nonces.'}, {'account_id': 1075, 'date': '2013-02-09 03:55:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

So trusted messaging sounds like, any service(nova-compute etc) have its credentials, and sending messages with hash value generated using its credentials, correct?'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-02-09 04:14:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Trusted messaging will bring digital signatures which is a better term in this case than simply "a message hash", as simple hashes such as SHA alone wouldn't provide what is needed in terms of confidence. This patch has little to do directly with trusted messaging other than having a common requirement.

However, digital signing alone will not prevent someone from taking a legitimate message that was previously signed in good confidence and good faith, and putting it back onto the message bus. The message would be valid and would have a valid signature, but it shouldn't be processed. This is referred to as a replay attack.'}, {'account_id': 6539, 'date': '2013-02-09 04:50:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

I have comments on the code, but do not want to request more changes until we resolve whether trusted messages affect this patch.  I would think trusted messages would be optional and not backward compatible.  This patch is always on and is backward and forward compatible.  Maybe Eric is suggesting that we can add some message ID in this patch that trusted messages could also use.  If so, Eric, please clarify.  Otherwise, let's proceed with the review."}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-02-09 05:05:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

I'm not suggesting this be based on or dependent on trusted messaging, but that trusted messaging has requirements from a no-duplicated-messages feature that this patch does not address. This patch doesn't really leave any position for adding those features, but would end up being reverted.

If it survives into Grizzly-final, we could still revert as long as the msg_id_nc field remained in Havana for compatibility purposes.

I still prefer we just do it once and do it right. The main point is *where* in the code this is done. The rest are details stemming from that point.

Basically, the duplication checking should happen in rpc/common.py and performed before deserialization of the message."}, {'account_id': 6539, 'date': '2013-02-09 05:16:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

So you are suggesting that the entire change be put in rpc/common.py.  You mentioned adding the duplicate checking to the deserialize_msg() method.  With your suggestion wouldn't adding the message ID be done in serialize_msg()?

This is a frustratingly late request.  The original patch was specific to RabbitMQ, but was asked to be generalized for all AMQP based RPCs.  Now it is being asked to be generalized for all RPCs.

Is the justification for this that the message id added in rpc/common.py could be used by the trusted messaging code?  Or is the justification that it would be nice to have to ZMQ too?  Or both?"}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-02-09 05:32:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

I do apologize that I hadn't stumbled upon this review earlier.

> "Is the justification for this that the message id added in rpc/common.py 
> could be used by the trusted messaging code? Or is the justification that it 
> would be nice to have to ZMQ too? Or both?"

Both. Also, it will be better performant?

> With your suggestion wouldn't adding the message ID be done
> in serialize_msg()?

Yes, in or around it.'}, {'account_id': 6539, 'date': '2013-02-09 06:27:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Well, I think the change would be easier/cleaner in rpc/common.py.  I'm not sure impl_zmq.py could handle the raised duplicate message exception.  The AMQP based implementations catch the exception so that they can send an ack() for the message.

A common mistake is to think performance is a concern on an error path.  Sorry, I am primarily performance engineer.

If you say it is good for ZMQ, then I have no problem with moving it to rpc/common.py"}, {'account_id': 1075, 'date': '2013-02-09 07:02:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

BTW, trusted messaging implementation is on time for grizzly? Just curious.

Raymond: <https://review.openstack.org/#/c/20240/> is on the way. I add new comment. please check it..'}, {'account_id': 6539, 'date': '2013-02-10 15:33:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

I think the consensus is that Kei should submit another patch with the duplicate checking added to rpc/common.py serialize_msg() and deserialize_msg().  Since the RPC envelope will be disabled in Grizzly and we want this duplicate message bug fix to be enabled for Grizzly, the duplicate checking ID would have to be added outside of the envelope.

That brings up a question of whether it should be different when the envelope is enabled.  Should it go inside the envelope and the code made aware that if an envelope exists to look for the ID there instead of as part of the base message?

What name should be given this new ID?  one_way_msg_id, security_id, confidence_id, reliability_id, trust_id, integrety_id.  Russell made a comment in the past that it should be called what it is, not what it is used for.  The one_way_msg_id comes closest to that.  The AMQP msg_id is more like a two way msg_id since it describes something about the return path of the message.  If this ID were to be added to serialize/deserialize, it would be a different value on the call request versus call response.

I think we owe Kei some direction here.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2013-02-10 16:33:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Ray: I hadn't really intending to "steal" this, but since I had a good idea of what I'm looking for here and already started on an alternative. I have a review up, but it needs some fixes yet:

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-27 17:51:57.000000000', 'message': 'Fix "Needs to skip duplicated messages when using rabbitmq mirrored queue"

On using rabbitmq mirrored queue, openstack service may handle the same
message twice when rabbitmq is down after receiving a message,
dispatching to a specific method, and before sending ack to rabbitmq.
In this case, message is not deleted, then openstack service receives
same message after it reconnect to slave rabbitmq. This situation causes
an error since the message is already dispatched to a specific method.
This patch is to store previous message and skip if openstack service
receive same message as previous one.

Fixes bugs 1107064.

Change-Id: I5bfacadbdf7de8b34d6370b9aa869c271957692d

'}, {'created': '2013-02-22 11:49:33.000000000', 'message': 'Fix "AMQP: skip duplicate messages"

When using rabbit's mirrored queues or qpid's replicated queues, there
are conditions under which you can receive the same message twice.

One such condition is where a message has been sent to a consumer but
before an ack is received by a consumer, the master fails over to a
slave and the slave resends the message. Note that the consumer may have
sent the ack, but it was lost as the master went down.

Dispatching the same message twice is obviously something we want to
avoid. In order to do so, we add a unique_id to each message sent and
have consumers maintain a fixed length queue of recently seen unique
message IDs. Before dispatching any received message, the queue is
checked and the message is skipped if it is a duplicate.

Fixes bugs 1107064.

Change-Id: I5bfacadbdf7de8b34d6370b9aa869c271957692d

commit_message:
AMQP: skip duplicate messages

When using rabbit's mirrored queues or qpid's replicated queues, there
are conditions under which you can receive the same message twice.

One such condition is where a message has been sent to a consumer but
before an ack is received by a consumer, the master fails over to a
slave and the slave resends the message. Note that the consumer may have
sent the ack, but it was lost as the master went down.

Dispatching the same message twice is obviously something we want to
avoid. In order to do so, we add a unique_id to each message sent and
have consumers maintain a fixed length queue of recently seen unique
message IDs. Before dispatching any received message, the queue is
checked and the message is skipped if it is a duplicate.

Fixes bugs 1107064.

Change-Id: I5bfacadbdf7de8b34d6370b9aa869c271957692d

commit_message:
CLI support for network gateway feature

Blueprint nvp-nwgw-extension-client

Adds commands for gateway management, and for connecting
networks to gateways. These commands use the nicira-specific
extension 'nvp-network-gateway'

Change-Id: Iefcba201bc9fd8dce35762514af0f56b29430ccd

commit_message:
refactor LoadBalancerPluginDbTestCase setUp()

fixes bug: 1129417

This fixes the bug by changing LoadBalancerPluginDbTestCase to inherit
from test_db_plugin.QuantumDbPluginV2TestCase.  This allows for the
plugin to access context managers for core resources.  Additionally,
this change adds subresource and service_plugin support to
QuantumDbPluginV2TestCase.

Change-Id: I5e838a3df6d4c7192d4a738d3860f3a162cb5a8c

commit_message:
Remove compat cfg wrapper

This wrapper was there to allow oslo-config changes through the gate
while keystoneclient hadn't been updated.

Change-Id: I3d48673af58ae379e8e4d2c7fb4b4d81f3ed67dd

If we would like to change the default behavior of OVS/LB plugin, i have another idea to override dhcp_agent_manager to DhcpAgent if agent extension is not supported. It does not break the behavior of plugins which do not support the agent extension."}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-02-23 20:49:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
AttributeError: No such RPC function 'report_state'

This patch changes dhcp_agent_manager to be DhcpAgent instead of
DhcpAgentWithStateReport since not all plugins support DhcpAgentWithStateReport
and having this as the default breaks all current deployments that upgrade
source without changing their config files.

Fixes bug 1131446

Change-Id: I6415f85714b03e9bf59d597e8ec2397fedc92b02

commit_message:
Avoid using logging in signal handlers

Fixes bug 1029727

It is possible for logging to cause problems during signal handlers.
Fortunately, the logging we have in signal handlers is minimal and does
not add enough value to try to keep through workarounds.

Change-Id: I80708874c9740c906e5a49e0d9c1b45174470a85

[{'created': '2013-02-22 22:06:53.000000000', 'message': 'Support qpid as message provider for ceilometer

Previously, the RPC backend was hardcoded to the appropriate
dirver for rabbitMQ only.

Now we allow qpid to be used as an alternative.

Note that ZeroMQ is not tested or supported as yet.

Change-Id: If9a69a4c52f046fc6e3530b47542d55438787cea
'}]
commit_message:
Support qpid as message provider for ceilometer

Previously, the RPC backend was hardcoded to the appropriate
dirver for rabbitMQ only.

Now we allow qpid to be used as an alternative.

Note that ZeroMQ is not tested or supported as yet.

Change-Id: If9a69a4c52f046fc6e3530b47542d55438787cea

Correct SQL migration 017 column name

The user_project_membership still uses tenant_id and not project_id
as a column name, the migration code uses project_id for both tables.

Fixed bug 1130424

Change-Id: Id7c9f78235ad87103ecf469bea312e6291c0a327

[{'created': '2013-02-22 21:52:48.000000000', 'message': 'Correct location of computevncconsole in -install

An XInclude resource error was being raised
when building openstack-install due to a file
being named differently than referenced via
bk_installdashboard.xml.

This fixes the reference such that it
refers to compute-vnc-console.xml,
not computevncconsole.xml.

Fixes bug 1131939.

Change-Id: Ie5751b6e63cd80894eb113ebaac161fe625a5c95
'}]
commit_message:
Correct location of computevncconsole in -install

An XInclude resource error was being raised
when building openstack-install due to a file
being named differently than referenced via
bk_installdashboard.xml.

This fixes the reference such that it
refers to compute-vnc-console.xml,
not computevncconsole.xml.

Fixes bug 1131939.

Change-Id: Ie5751b6e63cd80894eb113ebaac161fe625a5c95

subject: Adding ability to specify the libvirt cache mode for disk devices
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 1501, 'name': 'Phil Day', 'email': 'philip.day@hp.com', 'username': 'philip-day'}, {'_account_id': 1525, 'name': 'Rafi Khardalian', 'email': 'rafi@metacloud.com', 'username': 'rkhardalian'}, {'_account_id': 1779, 'name': 'Daniel Berrange', 'email': 'berrange@redhat.com', 'username': 'berrange'}, {'_account_id': 1882, 'name': 'dave-mcnally', 'email': 'dave.mcnally@hpe.com', 'username': 'dave-mcnally'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2750, 'name': 'Sean Dague', 'email': 'sean@dague.net', 'username': 'sdague'}, {'_account_id': 2889, 'name': 'Aeva Black', 'email': 'aeva.online@gmail.com', 'username': 'tenbrae'}, {'_account_id': 4393, 'name': 'Dan Smith', 'email': 'dms@danplanet.com', 'username': 'danms'}, {'_account_id': 5174, 'name': 'Mauro Rodrigues', 'email': 'maurosr@linux.vnet.ibm.com', 'username': 'maurosr'}, {'_account_id': 5638, 'name': 'Davanum Srinivas', 'email': 'davanum@gmail.com', 'username': 'dims-v'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-12-13 15:37:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/18042/1/check/gate-nova-merge/13969 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/18042/1/check/gate-nova-docs/9687 : SUCCESS
